												You are a badger; you have 5 children who need food; turnips, apples, frogs, rats, foxes are food that can be found/caught; wolves, floods, fire and eagles are trying to eat/kill your kids; keep them alive and kepe them fed. This game is incredible. Such a simple concept and yet so enjoyable. It's the kind of game where you can get a beer, and just sit down and play without having to be totally invested, mentally, in what is going on. It has a simplistic art style that reminds me of children's bedtime books, and a wonderful soundtrack that is relaxing and yet telling of events both happening and coming. It's not a long game, but it is totally worth every penny you spend on it.

You will jump 5 meters in the air, break a fox's neck as a breadstick and set an entire forest on fire!Meanwhile your sons will grow up and became bigger than you, but still won't help you hunting or running out of dangers, just as real life sons would do!Soon you will sadly realize your actions are meaningless: badgers will die no matter what and they will grow up no matter how much food you will give them. This won't stop you playing the game until the (easily guessed) end, a measily 1 hour and half after the beginning.It's like Christmas: it's fun until you find the secret that lies behind :( .Best played with Keyboard and MouseRecommended Buy Price < 3$Score 7/10

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												This game is by 'Might and Delight' found here http://www.mightanddelight.com/index.php?page=projects where you can also pick up some free desk top screen savers for shelter and a children's book with the same art style.Shelter is a mother badger simulation which harbors a Picasso type look to it all. The objective is to simply look after your five children and keep them alive against such difficulties and enemies such as starvation, predators, flash floods and bush fires. In truth the real enemy here is you and how neglectful you are as a mother. More than likely you will witness your children's helpless faces as they get washed away, burned like popcorn, waste away to nothing because you haven't fed them in the last five seconds, or you will simply hear what their screams and bones sound like as they get munched on by the pigs or hyena's that hunt in the night like they are velociraptors. The game is short lived as it only has five levels and a bonus tamagotchi level called 'nuture'. The game never holds your hand by telling you what you need to do and so more often than not you will find out the hard way through sacrifice. It isn't extremely difficult to complete this game with all five children still alive on your second run through, but it is on your first run though.You will learn various things in this game. You will learn what it means to be in the wild. You will learn the need to distinguish your children and not play favorites. You will learn the need to keep your children in the safety view of your watchful eye. You will learn to look ahead for danger, look for easier paths that do not encourage your children to be distracted from danger and you will learn to scavenge for food. It also teaches you that headbutting things will get you far in life, something that no doubt is useful in the real world too.The nuture game is a tamagotchi which requires you to log in daily and nuture your five cubs back to health. Each day you will find 1 or 2 food items. Once the children have been fed about 7 times they will then start to venture with you to the exit of the burrow. After day 7 you will be given a chance to venture further and be given access to the river. As days progress your game level and experiences progress. The limit of this experience is 365 days. You cannot progress any further after that. This level seems to have just been added as an after thought to add some more padding to the game in general and what's on offer.Highly recommend the game and at least a complete single play through so you can experience it for yourself if it ever goes on sale. You can also see a complete run through of the game here... https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLGoldgfYpB4ARdxvMTpOpEwRYguTLZoK5

content:
Posted: September 7, 2013
												Don't expect another Journey here, but just a well made adventure starring badgers. It's your goal, as mother badger, to shelter your cubs from harm in this one hour adventure. An original idea, I agree, and in the time it takes to finish you will experience several situations that might change the story. The whole game takes place in the woods, so it's all colorful and detailed (as far as the graphical style allows). There isn't a whole lot of action, so the gameplay is a bit on the slow side, but you shouldn't get bored of it before the end.I, for one, enjoy and welcome games like this, because they usually try to tell a(n emotional) story. Ok, the gameplay may be non-existent, but the experience itself is usually worth the journey. So I guess you could interpret that as a compliment (which it is in this case :))..[Rating: 78/100]

content:
Posted: November 19, 2016
												Well, what can I really say? The only thing this game has going for it is the artstyle. The game is extremly short, it can be easily beaten in under 2 hours. The levels are very different from one another, but the gameplay is almost always the same: you get your cubs food by either slaming yourself against the apple tree ( and only the apple tree) or you pull food out from the ground, occasionaly you might get the chance to catch a frog or a mice or even a fox ( last one being extremly hard to catch). The only enemy you have to worry about is the giant eagle, but he only appears at certain areas of the game, so no constant threats. The game sadly never shows any heartwarming bounding moments between you and your cubs, so the ending is rather dissapointing, feels very forced and sudden. So, all in all, I would skip this one and maybe check out the other 2 games from the same studio, which is what I will do next.

Posted: April 16, 2014
												Honestly when I picked this up I wasn't expecting much from it, I kind of wrote it off as just another artsy eco-message game, but I figured I'd give it a shot for the sake of making a let's play video of it.Turns out I was in for more than I expected.The game really sucks you in. What I was planning on being just a "Let's Play" video turned into a full playthrough.It's engrossing. While I'm not a fan of the incredibly overdone gamma/brightness, and at times the textures they use are a bit over the top, the game is a solid bit of fun. You genuinely start to worry about your little babies (It helps they all have unique markings), and you don't want to see anything bad happen to them. (Though the environment is all too willing to shorten their lives.)Yes it's short (I finished it in a couple of hours), and the graphic style might be a bit much for some, but despite my preconceptions about the game, it got me to do something a lot of other games have not been able to do. It made me care.It was almost an emotional experience, and not one I'm going to forget anytime soon.If you want to try a break from the norm, this might have something for you.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												Shelter is probably one of the most bring games ever conceived in the entire history of computer games, and that also includes consoles.Considering the game was released in 2013, when multi-GPU systems, with hundreds of GPU cores are relatively common, this games graphics are awful. It is something that would perhaps be nice in the 90's, in the era of the 3DFx Voodoo accelerators, but nowadays these graphics don't have any appeal. PLayability is close to nil: there is no hint of what must and should be done in the game. You start as a badger with its 4 cubs in a cave. So, what now? The game doesn't tip you anything. You might as well stay in the cave. Actually, due to some bug in the game, the badge can't even exit the cave.As other users have put it, Shelter is just a plain boring badger simulator, although watching your neighbour's grass grow is a lot more entertaining.I strongly advise you NOT to get this game. It is a shame how developers even wasted time and effort on a game like this.

Posted: April 7, 2014
												Shelter is an incredible experience. For short, this game is like a long escort mission. I enjoy the game at first and it simply gets old halfway for me but I recommend this game because of the reasonable price.I got this game during Steam Weekend Deals for 2 dollars. So far, I've played 82 minutes into the game I haven't survived yet. I know I'm going to keep coming back to play Shelter until I managed to escort all five cubs to the end game.It may sound like a simple escort but you need to feed those cubs and make sure that they are not fallen victim to nature's wrath. The jungle can be nice and peaceful but can also be unforgiving.

Posted: May 13, 2014
												As a as a strict, hardcore indie gamer and as an indie developer myself, I really liked this game. The concept of playing as an animal is good enough, but caring for your adorable offspring is a fantastic idea and I wish I came up with it first. The mechanics work, and gameplay is usually varied. I got extremely attached to my cubs, even naming them (R.IP. O.J. Simpson, Sheriff Willins and Mailtime). I also really like the art style. It worked with the square issue that textured objects face to create a nice, homy quilt feel. And also the endgame. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ I can't believe they ended the game like that. I cried my eyes out.     The one thing I didn't like about this game was that it was very linear. There were little opportunities for exploration and the objective seemed too clear. This might be a minor issue for some people, but I am not a big fan of linear games. Also, it is kinda short, which I don't mind too much, but I did pay $10 for this game. Shelter, however, makes up for this by controlling your emotions.     Other than that however, the mechanics work, the art style is nice and it plays with your emotions a lot. A LOT. Shelter is worth $10, and if you get it on sale, use the money you saved to buy tissues. I am very excited for Shelter 2, as in that one you play as bobcats, which probably means you won't get tracked down by that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hawk. Scroll down for spoilers.FINAL VERDICT:Pass me the tissues8.8/10--------------------------------------------- As River Song would say, "Spoilers!" ---------------------------------------------At the end, you are stuck in a wide open field with no tall grass for your cubs to hide in. The hawk first takes one of your pups (poor Mailtime) and goes away for a little while. When she comes back, she proceeds to punch you, then comes around for another punch and so on. Eventually you get so groggy that your babies run off without you, and then the hawk picks you up and carries you off to its nest. There's a shot of your remaining pups walking off into the wilderness, crying, and then the credits roll (insert sobbing here). After the credits, the game then ends with a shot of the hawk carrying your body to its nest full of hungry baby birds. The end. Proceed to bawl even more.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												This game is truely adorable. It's also a rare gem among games. What I mean when I say that is that animal simulator games seem to be SO rare... Why is this?? Many people have played, play and love this game. Think about it for a while... Maybe there should be more games like this? I have to say I'm disappointed to find that Shelter is the only game on Steam that allows you to play a animal! Why is that? Do some people think that animals would make for a boring game? I must say I give this game 5 stars for beauty, cuteness, easy controls, etc. But yes. Please let there be many more games just like Shelter. Would horses, birds, wolves, any sort of animal be too hard to ask for in a game?Bravo, creators, bravo!However, I have ONE complaint. The game is far too short. And the ending is scripted, no way to pass it alive. It IS possible to pass with all 5 cubs however. Anyway, I'd love it if Might and Delight tried to make another game like this. I would defently get it!Thank you for reading this, I hope that it's inspiring to the creators AND everyone else.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												I'm usually the type of guy who is slower at completing a game than other people, but I managed to finish this in 1.5 hours.  No complain in regards to the length of this game; in fact, I find that the length of it is just adequate.  If the game is longer, I probably couldn't have finished it in one sitting, and that would destroy the whole experience of it. By the way, I think if anyone going to play this game, it's best to finish it in one sitting.  It's like you watch a whole movie, except it is better; because you are more involved in it, you are controlling the badger in the game, and you are more attached to it.So, this game is all about playing mother badger sheltering her cubs from harm.  And there really isn't any story or plot in this game, but it makes you think about the deeper things that you normally won't think about.  After I finished this game, I thought about it for a long time, even when I'm lying on bed.  I thought about the existence of these badger, the existence of myself, or just life in general. Nowadays, I've been playing and looking for games that's 'different' from others.  And I truly hope there are more games like this one.  I highly recommend this if you want a unique and wonderful gaming experience.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												Let's get the essentials out of the way: a. Shelter is short. b. Shelter is not an open-world survival sim, or even, really, aiming to be a realistic survival sim at all, beyond the fact that you're keeping five badger kits alive for two hours. Or . . . trying to. Gameplay's pretty simple. Feed your babies. Don't let them get eaten, drowned, or set on fire. And that's it. But simple as it is, it's a game you can screw up, or a game that can screw you up. Helps that the babies and the landscape are both lovingly designed, and so you're all I must protect you babies, but this landscape wants to devour you and I can't just put you in a safe basket and drag you through the four or five levels, here. When the game's working best, it's anxiety-inducing to lose track of your kids. I had this one point where I thought I lost all of them, and I ended up running my badger around in circles in a broad simulation of aaaaaah. It's good for that. Keep in mind.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												Shelter is probably one of the most bring games ever conceived in the entire history of computer games, and that also includes consoles.Considering the game was released in 2013, when multi-GPU systems, with hundreds of GPU cores are relatively common, this games graphics are awful. It is something that would perhaps be nice in the 90's, in the era of the 3DFx Voodoo accelerators, but nowadays these graphics don't have any appeal. PLayability is close to nil: there is no hint of what must and should be done in the game. You start as a badger with its 4 cubs in a cave. So, what now? The game doesn't tip you anything. You might as well stay in the cave. Actually, due to some bug in the game, the badge can't even exit the cave.As other users have put it, Shelter is just a plain boring badger simulator, although watching your neighbour's grass grow is a lot more entertaining.I strongly advise you NOT to get this game. It is a shame how developers even wasted time and effort on a game like this.

Posted: January 28, 2014
												Nature is beautiful, nature is terrifying.Death is inevitable, but breeds life.Also, one of my babies was eaten by a Gru.I had a lot of fun in this game, despite being irritated by the unclear intentions for the grayed out cub in the beginning. The graphics are what they are, and I feel that's sufficient for this game. Music is nice and atmospheric, if a bit repetitive sometimes. I ended the game with two of five cubs surviving, one having been taken by the night, one drowning, and one deciding it wanted food more than avoiding the bird stalking it.A note on the ending. It surprised me in a good way. The whole time I was thinking to myself "No! No! Gotta find some cover!"When I realized what was going on, it inspired my first sentences here. Those two lines sum up the entire game quite nicely.

												This is a great game. A true gem among thousands of games. It might be really short but you get a lot. The game is supposed to teach you about the balance of life and about the mothers attempts to take care of her younglings. Posted: May 16, 2015
												Very intense game. Watching as my first badger was snatched right before my eyes sunk my heart. You want to protect your badgers not through player rewards, but through the calls and behaviors of the pups. Seeing them get excited and start hopping around a carrot that they cannot get without your help makes you want to stop, go back, and get that carrot for them. They reward you with such nice squeaks. When they get scared or attacked, they release a heart piercing cry. The badger cubs are helpless without you. They know it, and try to stay by your side. Seeing that vulnerability brings out a powerful empathetic sense of duty to protect them. It makes it so devastating when you fail. Disappointingly short, but it gets it's whole story told without feeling rushed. Once the last act started, if felt like the final act. I was not surprised or confused by the end. It made sense and provided a sense of conclusion that was very appropriate.I've been playing many games over many years, but Shelter is the first time that I was so moved that I felt the need to post a review. I purchased this game because of the beautiful polygonal art and I loved the concept of being a badger mother hunting for food while protecting her cubs. Would have been pretty happy simply enjoying the distinct plot, but this emotional roller coaster stole the show.I'm forever impacted by Shelter's use of character sounds and behaviors to elicit rewards and punishments.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												I'm biased right from the start because I've always wanted some good wildlife-simulation games where you play as wild animals trying to survive nature.This one has a beautiful but simple style. My only complaint regarding the visuals is that I find the light pastel color scheme a little difficult to make out. This lack of contrast is difficult both because you might not be able to see little tunnels to dive into for cover, and because you tell which of your babies is hungry by them becoming paler. So, you kind of have to be able to tell the difference between "already pale" and "a little more pale".The controls are also fairly simple. The game does a pretty good job of informing you what controls perform what fucntion, but like many indie games, it leaves you to figure out when to use them. I kind of like this, because I find a lot fo games these days really hold my hand and don't let me experiment much.The main game is short and very linear, though it's not too short for me to feel emotionally attached to the pups ones. The difficulty is far from impossible, but just challenging enough. Despite the short length and simple gameplay, I keep coming back because I hope to eventually have a playthrough where all of my little ones survive.I think I'd give this about an 8.5/10. It was definitely worth playing, even at the regular $9.99 price. -1 for the low-contrast graphics, and -0.5 for the length.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												Was actually an incredibly engaging game that tugged on the heartstrings. Made the mistake of naming my cubs... actually got attatched to them. The choice to emphasize on lighting and surreal, painted textures was a good one. It only immersed you more into this storybook setting, which was lighthearted and sweet at first but quickly became a world full of danger and hardship, though there was still beauty. Buy this game. It's worth it.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												I applaud a game for being different and not being scared to be niche. A badger and her offspring simulator isn't something for everyone's tastes, but if you are into wildlife (as I am) you will probably enjoy this.Pros:While the game is fairly linear, the levels are constructed in a way that most of them feel open enough that you don't notice.There is a good sense of tension of keeping you and your offspring alive against the odds of nature.Cons:The gamma in the opening level is way too brightThe torch light in the night level is highly distracting and unrealisticBadgers are nocturnal and this isn't reflected in the gameplayBadgers keen sense of smell isn't in the gameBadgers attacking foxes? Highly unlikely.Overall I liked it, but it has its issues, so I would give it a score of about 70%

												I'm naked and my kids are ♥♥♥♥ing idiots

Posted: December 10, 2013
												I'm not going to spend too much time describing this game because you should experience it yourself if you are going to play it. If I had to put it in two sentences though I'd say: "Shelter is a game where you play as a badger in a forest where everyone and everything hates your species. Especially birds".The game itself is actually very pretty! The artstyle they used was really interesting and it has a few great "background shot" moments. Soundtrack is pretty mesmerizing. Stuff you don't usually hear in video games. There are some problems with framerate and some pretty harsh pop-in. Pop-in is something I would never want to see in an "experience game" like this. It does a good job of pulling you out of the experience. Shelter is not a long game (1 hour if you don't rush through it) but I didn't feel like it should have been longer. It teaches you a thing or two about nature. For full price I can't recommend it but for heavily discounted price get it. You should look up some similiar "experience" type of games like Journey, Dear Esther and Stanley Parable and if you are not afraid of lack of gameplay then get on this. It's not the best of its kind but it's definitely not the worst either. If you have it backlogged get on it instead of reading this. It's definitely worth your time.

Posted: April 15, 2014
												Short but sweet. Some may scoff at the pricetag for 1h30m playtime, but overall, I was pleased with what I signed up for. The only really problem I have is that quite a few parts have rather irritating invisible walls, instead of designing the levels in ways that the player doesn't feel as compelled to push those boundaries. Either way, the intent was achieved, the game quickly succeeds in making you feel responsible for your younglings and most definitely creates an emotional bond towards the end. If that description tickles your fancy, I heavily recommend it. I'm eager for the sequel anyhow.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Shelter is a very gorgeous game.The graphics are simple but lovely, the feelings for your children so authentic as the fear of the 'enemies'. The gameplay works better than in the most AAA titles you can find on the market nowadays and the ambientmusic in the background works perfect and supports the action on the screen.Although it's short I think it's near a perfect game and if you think what you would get for this money from a AAA studio, then I would totally recommend Shelter and say it's worth every single cent.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												This a lovely, and potentially saddening game.  It is made me think of the trials and tribulations that a mother goes through.  I felt so terrible each time one of my cubs died, and felt awful when I had only one left.  Then felt like crushed as a hawk swooped my last cub away.  When the hawk returned and killed me, as I tried to sprinit for cover, then hobble, then crawl as it attacked me, I felt I deserved it.  Yet, in the end, the hawk was just feeding its' chicks.I really love the pro-Mother aspect of this game, and that the creators thank all mothers in the credits.  Also, the music is quite good and atmospheric.

Posted: December 21, 2013
												I bought this game on impulse mainly based off the graphica appearance of it. Yes, it's not revolutionary or fancy, but it is a very pretty game in it's own simple, pastel-tinted way.For a game that just focuses on your protecting your little of badger cubs, I both enjoyed and suffered through it very much. It has very simple gameplay mechanics that work and the story isn't blown out of proportion in anyway. This is nature and this is life. You have to protect your babies or feel the sting of losing them, which I admittedly felt a few times after losing one or two cubs.It's short, yes, which is a shame, as I do really love the atmoshpher and the design, but it accomplishes what it set out to do.

Posted: April 7, 2014
												Shelter is an incredible experience. For short, this game is like a long escort mission. I enjoy the game at first and it simply gets old halfway for me but I recommend this game because of the reasonable price.I got this game during Steam Weekend Deals for 2 dollars. So far, I've played 82 minutes into the game I haven't survived yet. I know I'm going to keep coming back to play Shelter until I managed to escort all five cubs to the end game.It may sound like a simple escort but you need to feed those cubs and make sure that they are not fallen victim to nature's wrath. The jungle can be nice and peaceful but can also be unforgiving.

Posted: April 16, 2014
												Honestly when I picked this up I wasn't expecting much from it, I kind of wrote it off as just another artsy eco-message game, but I figured I'd give it a shot for the sake of making a let's play video of it.Turns out I was in for more than I expected.The game really sucks you in. What I was planning on being just a "Let's Play" video turned into a full playthrough.It's engrossing. While I'm not a fan of the incredibly overdone gamma/brightness, and at times the textures they use are a bit over the top, the game is a solid bit of fun. You genuinely start to worry about your little babies (It helps they all have unique markings), and you don't want to see anything bad happen to them. (Though the environment is all too willing to shorten their lives.)Yes it's short (I finished it in a couple of hours), and the graphic style might be a bit much for some, but despite my preconceptions about the game, it got me to do something a lot of other games have not been able to do. It made me care.It was almost an emotional experience, and not one I'm going to forget anytime soon.If you want to try a break from the norm, this might have something for you.

Posted: May 13, 2014
												As a as a strict, hardcore indie gamer and as an indie developer myself, I really liked this game. The concept of playing as an animal is good enough, but caring for your adorable offspring is a fantastic idea and I wish I came up with it first. The mechanics work, and gameplay is usually varied. I got extremely attached to my cubs, even naming them (R.IP. O.J. Simpson, Sheriff Willins and Mailtime). I also really like the art style. It worked with the square issue that textured objects face to create a nice, homy quilt feel. And also the endgame. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ I can't believe they ended the game like that. I cried my eyes out.     The one thing I didn't like about this game was that it was very linear. There were little opportunities for exploration and the objective seemed too clear. This might be a minor issue for some people, but I am not a big fan of linear games. Also, it is kinda short, which I don't mind too much, but I did pay $10 for this game. Shelter, however, makes up for this by controlling your emotions.     Other than that however, the mechanics work, the art style is nice and it plays with your emotions a lot. A LOT. Shelter is worth $10, and if you get it on sale, use the money you saved to buy tissues. I am very excited for Shelter 2, as in that one you play as bobcats, which probably means you won't get tracked down by that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hawk. Scroll down for spoilers.FINAL VERDICT:Pass me the tissues8.8/10--------------------------------------------- As River Song would say, "Spoilers!" ---------------------------------------------At the end, you are stuck in a wide open field with no tall grass for your cubs to hide in. The hawk first takes one of your pups (poor Mailtime) and goes away for a little while. When she comes back, she proceeds to punch you, then comes around for another punch and so on. Eventually you get so groggy that your babies run off without you, and then the hawk picks you up and carries you off to its nest. There's a shot of your remaining pups walking off into the wilderness, crying, and then the credits roll (insert sobbing here). After the credits, the game then ends with a shot of the hawk carrying your body to its nest full of hungry baby birds. The end. Proceed to bawl even more.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2015
												I am a male that is 6'8" tall.I've no aspiration whatsoever to raise children; for "an accident" to happen is one of my greatest fears...I just completed one (of the apparent five) levels in Shelter. That was more tense than most gritty action games; every few seconds, I would panic and swing the camera around "WHERE ARE MY BEHBEHZ??!?!?!?!?!!" And that Pokémon at the'nd of the level, straight circlin', waitin for one of muh behbehz to be a little too slow... I had to quit the game right there. There's only so much strain my heart can take. The art-style... th-the art-style... oh my, the art-style... (although, I would appreciate some sort of contrast options, unless the colors are meant to look like - er let's see 'f'I can get the terminology correct - washed watercolor, i.e. not vivid at all, to the point that it makes me feel the need to tweak my TV's color settings - the colors themselves are very subdued - every one of the colors within the environments is so bright (as in mixed heavily with white) that yeah, it's a little... off(?)))I recommend this gameEDIT: 1.4 hrs to beat the game. I've read there are different endings. I made it to the end with 4 of my 5 chil'ren alive. Dat ending doe... Throughout the game, it was actually rare for me to be contemplative of the ways of Nature - the game is basically a walking simulator as a badger, in which you can pick up (rarely hunt) food and get to watch the scenery change (two (maybe three) different instances force you to respond to the environment in a different way - which might not be bad when considering the 5 levels, but still - not much to it, but that could be argued as a strength so IDK). Really, that's what I got from most of the game. The ending actually made a statement like I assume the whole game was meant to, though. It's a neat game - not sure if I'd call it "good" necessarily but I did like it and it is worth checking for something different. I wonder how much more complex Shelter 2 will be.

Posted: April 1, 2014
												One of your cubs is growing hungry, but you look ahead and see nothing but tall grass and weeds. It is only a matter of time before all of your kits are starving. You are their mother, their protector, their role model, and their lifeline. It is up to you to protect them from anything and everything nature can muster.Shelter is a game that will tug at your heart strings. You'll find yourself turning around to check on your little ones almost constantly. Are they hungry? Has one run off? Are they falling behind? Shelter will only take you 1-2 hours to finish; however, it is worth every penny if you invest yourself into it - only then will it become an amazing test of parenthood and a story that you'll not be able to forget.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Shelter is a beautiful and charming game where you are a mother badger tasked with the responsibilities of taking care of your five pups. Some players may find this simulation too linear, but the structure allows for it to be divided into chapters which shake up the mainly slow-paced action. The game is beautiful, made up of pastel textures stitched onto the world which change with the acts and colour palettes. It is a heartwarming journey in which you are able to witness the growth of your pups as they grow in size and speed, but it leaves you with a gnawing sense of failure in the almost inevitable death of your pups due to hunger, predation or just nature itself. The ending is an ode to motherhood that leaves you with a sense of legacy, grief and hope. It's only around 2 hours long, so probably wait for a sale, but it's worth it.

Posted: April 24, 2015
												This is a spoilerfree review of an entire playthrough of the game.In Shelter you play as a mother-badger trying to protect her baby badgers while guiding them through one danger after another. Like really, staying in the beginning cave would have been a better idea but whatever. The question you have to ask yourself is this: Is that enough for you to care? The game doesnt give you more than "these are your children you are the mother protect them" as a reason to care. The artstyle is interesting I wouldn't say good nor bad. The problem with it is that your baby badgers really dont look cute. They squeak in a kind of cute way and that is as good as it gets. This leads to my first problem: I didnt give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about my baby badgers. Of course I fed them since really there is nothing else to do in this game other than feeding walking and hiding. THe badgers stupidity doesnt help either. Lost 2 badgers to their own stupidity and another one was just suddenly gone without an explanation. That left me with 2 that I still didnt care all to much about. Those 2 made it to the end at least. The gameplay itself is a stealth escort mission that manages to be more annoying than most because of food problems and badger stupidity.  The music did its job, nothing I would buy. THe best moment I had in this game was when I accidently activated a bug and did a 12 meter superjump onto a non-expecting fox.  FAZIT: If you dont get attached to the badgers this game is a rather boring walking siumlator with food and stealth elements. And Badgers.P.S: Perhaps honey badgers would have been more appropriate, they dont care about all the dangers because they dont need to.

content:
Posted: January 6
												I want to say good things about this game but also go off on a giant rant of why I F'ing hate this game.Overall, I'd say this game is good if you're into this type of stuff. The arstyle is unique and it's relaxing in the parts that aren't stressful. The soundtrack is fitting. The game itself is incredibly simple; keep your babies alive (as many as you can) and follow the extremely linear path to the end of the game. It's no more than an hour long but the experience itself is something rather different. This was a very good game in my eyes despite the very short length and linear gameplay, though I wouldn't expect anything more considering how the game is.However, why I really, really hate this game is because of how ridiculously stressful it is. I don't know about anybody else but I'm a huge animal lover. I'm pretty sure my eyes teared up a bit when I lost one of my babies in the game and I had to go back (and cheat) to make sure that all of them stayed alive. Plus, the end of the game is SO, SO, SO FRUSTRATING. You go through the entire game trying to protect your babies and at the very end a hawk swoops down AS YOU ARE RUNNING TO THE FINISH LINE AND TAKES YOU UP INTO THE SKY TO IT'S NEST. And as you're flying up into the air in the hawk's clutching talons, you see your babies running off into the treeline without knowing if they will survive on their own or not. And if I recall correctly, the very end shows a hawk's nest with the mother badger (you) squealing in agony as it gets ripped apart by hungry baby eagles. I both F'ing love this game but F'ing hate it at the same time. But overall, I find it to be well done. Certainly a unique experience and an interesting game.

												While Shelter isn't a game as much as it is an interactive narrative, it nails just about every detail it could. Posted: March 23, 2014
												Very interesting! Could be a little disturbing at times, because this games makes You feel very much empathic to Your characters. I loved the simplicity and style of graphics, the coloring was brilliant. The idea is simply beautiful, sometimes You are left on the edge of Your seat. It's not a very easy game to play and I'm not sure how younger kids could receive it, because of the dangers the animals approach. There are parts that are really scary for a sensitive person, but all in all- very original and I'm quite sure- a must try game to those who are looking for something more different than usual big tittle games. I would also recommend this game to anyone who have fear related psychological issues in life. I'm very much convinced that many games can help overcome some of the psychological stuff we face in life. This one really helped me cope with some of the fears I had. It's basically like a training ground for Your own inner survival as much as a way to understand a little bit more. Of course there's always a timing issue with these things, but at the right time games like these can make their point in a persons life.

Posted: December 10, 2013
												I'm not going to spend too much time describing this game because you should experience it yourself if you are going to play it. If I had to put it in two sentences though I'd say: "Shelter is a game where you play as a badger in a forest where everyone and everything hates your species. Especially birds".The game itself is actually very pretty! The artstyle they used was really interesting and it has a few great "background shot" moments. Soundtrack is pretty mesmerizing. Stuff you don't usually hear in video games. There are some problems with framerate and some pretty harsh pop-in. Pop-in is something I would never want to see in an "experience game" like this. It does a good job of pulling you out of the experience. Shelter is not a long game (1 hour if you don't rush through it) but I didn't feel like it should have been longer. It teaches you a thing or two about nature. For full price I can't recommend it but for heavily discounted price get it. You should look up some similiar "experience" type of games like Journey, Dear Esther and Stanley Parable and if you are not afraid of lack of gameplay then get on this. It's not the best of its kind but it's definitely not the worst either. If you have it backlogged get on it instead of reading this. It's definitely worth your time.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												It's said that the greatest despair that a parent can face in life is the loss of a child.Shelter is a small story that you play which mimics parental love and the sorrow of loss by making you take care of five young badgers (You're the mommy badger) who need to be fed and protected as you go across the dangerous wilderness through day or night.I've noticed you should always try to keep them more or less fed at the same level or else the one that's least fed doesn't grow as much and becomes slower, therefore your possibility of loss of that young one is higher.I've loved playing this little story/simulation for it actually makes you want to protect the little ones as if it is your responsability - and when you lose one, it actually hurts.It also has a very distinct and great look to the game, with various textures to give that abstract depth of the wild life, the soundtrack choices are great for each moment...All I can say is that I loved it. Now it's time for you to find out if you're able to feel the pain of a mother.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Shelter is an intriguing concept the developer neglected to actually construct a game around.The mechanics are incredibly simple and never build in any way, such that any given minute of the game is virtually indistinguishable from any other minute. Go forward. Grab food. Occassionally go fast or go slow to avoid some hazard. There is no particular goal, no score kept, and no story, so there is no sense of progression or urgency.Your single goal is to keep the badger cubs alive, but they have no personality, no narrative surrounding them, and there is no penalty if they die, so there is no emotional connection to them: You won't really care if they die or not.I don't know how long the game is, because I didn't finish it, but however long it is, it's too long, because the game's charm wears off after about 15 minutes, and once the charm is gone, there is no reason to keep playing.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Due to the Steam Sale, I wound up picking a few games to add to my collection. One of which being a short indie titled called "Shelter". You play as a mother badger guiding her 5 pups through the woods to find a new home. Why? Because your small den won't be big enough for 5 quickly growing badger babies.Along the way, you need to feed them, protect them from fox (which they will eat if you manage to kill one), keep them from the preying eyes of eagles, and from the dangers of wildfire and rushing rivers.I managed to make it through the first time without a loss of offspring, so all five happy little fat badger babies made it to their new home.The ending was special.A very artisticly styled game that you can spend about an hour on to finish the story.  It was like watching an old story book moving around and easy to find yourself narrating it as you pitter patter around on your little badger toes.The replayability isn't overall very high, although if you didn't manage to make it through the first time with all 5 babies, challenge yourself to.

content:
Posted: January 2
												I'm into artsy visuals and gameplay, but this game didn't really satisfy me.It looks great, and the explanation of gameplay mechanics is well done, obviously with the principle "Show, don't tell" in mind. Also the general idea of playing badgers is cute.I barely got a chance to get emotionally attached to anything in this world. When my poor badger babies were stolen from me by nature's cruel hand, it didn't feel... sad? I was like "Oh man. Damn. Oh well.". It happened quickly and cheaply every time that it did happen, and neither the badger lady I was playing nor its brethren seemed to care at all. Basically, next to the cute idea of being a badger and the cute visuals, the game gave me no reason to feel attached to anything, no emotional buildup and all. Which is admittedly hard to do, when your game is as short!I feel like the lesson this game was trying to teach me was "Look how difficult it is to survive in this hostile and cruel world!". And yeah, sure, that's true. And then what?Without any emotional impact, there's not too much to take away from this game. The ending was anticlimactic, the gameplay mechanics that were there were really uninteresting - food was absolutely everywhere and felt like it had no impact, hunting the three kinds of other animals there were felt unnecessary and difficult - and most of the little gameplay time I have on this game, I spent waiting for my slow as ♥♥♥♥ badger babies to follow me.And sure, subpar gameplay can be excused when your game gives you a great story or atmosphere that you can lose yourself in, but I absolutely didn't feel that here. Towards the end of the game, I was ready to accept the walking-simulator-esque if I found some redeeming quality in it. And then the game ended, and there was no redeeming quality left to find. Unsurprisingly, replayability is close to zero as well. Can't really be arsed to go back and find SOME cute detail that I missed the first time that would make this game worth it.All in all, I don't think it's worth your time or money. It's not a lot of money, and it's not a lot of time, but personally, I didn't find it fun, and I got nothing out of it, emotionally. You might. Maybe not. Probably not.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Shelter is an experiment in what the medium of gaming can provide as an experience. It goes outside the mould of standard gaming conventions and instead chooses to tell a tale about a Badger mother who must look after her cubs while traversing vast distance in search of a new home. While the game is only about an hour long, it is one of those games that any game connoisseur should not miss out on.If you are only into games for the pointless grinding and getting as many hours out of a single game and exposure as you can until the value of that experience essentially approaches zero, this game is not for you. If you enjoy seeing the breadth and scope of the medium, and enjoy playing a large variety of games, this one is worth a look. Overall this game is a welcome venture into a way of play that should be expanded upon in the future to fully reach it's potential.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												I wanted to give it a positive review but I really can't. This game offers you an unique experience to be a badger mother and take care of 5 cubs while you pass few maps with predators lurking around. The actual game mode was okay, but I must say however the developer team didn't have as much budgets, if a majority of players actually have to go on the forum discussions just to check how and what to do in the very first 5 mins of the game, it is a bad sign. You should at least give people some sort of instructions, maybe an arrow pointing at the food on the ground (since really, the texture and color choices were horrible, it was so hard to make out the stuff to the eyes), not to mention the dumb precision of having to drop the food at the exact angle/spot. And don't even make me start on nurture mode. I was on Day--I think, 23 or 24? I have been repeating the same things over and over again for nearly a month and there was literally nothing that could tell me about when these cubs will leave or how this mode will end. You just don't expect people to mindlessly do this for everyday or two days without a sense of direction or time goal in mind. This tells you there was a serious lack of thinking in terms of developing and test-playing it in the players' perspective prior to the release. Anddd the result is pretty disastrous. I don't even want to touch this game when it's night/dark raining time in nurture mode, I just kept crashing into walls in the cave or kept getting lost in the map because it was wayyy too difficult to identify the surroundings. (Mind you, there is no map to show you your location or path) To be fair though, the real game mode's ending was quite a surprise and I could see it had somewhat educational purpose, which was good. But the more I play nurture mode, the more I think the developers could have done way better than that. I would have to give some consideration whether I should try out Shelter 2 or not in the future, but for now, I just completely lost any desire to do it. For people who want to try out this game, wait for a good sale maybe, and take my words: don't waste your time to dwell on nurture mode much. It's not worth it.

content:
Posted: March 6
The graphics certainly are unique and beautiful, yet I did not enjoy this game at all because of the dreadful gameplay and would not recommend it, unless you are solely playing it for the visuals.The premise of the game that you are a mother badger trying to feed your offspring and protect it from hazards sounds promising, but I found the gameplay to be an utter disappointment. The threat of death did not feel urgent and thus playing the game felt more like a walking simulator without any fascinating gameplay elements or comments. Despite the linearity, I found it often confusing where I was actually supposed to go, as the visuals are fuzzy in that regard, that you have to find your way through trial and error to get to the next level. I also didn't really feel emotionally invested in this game, which is what it relies mainly on.Absolutely not worth the asking price.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Right so i have been utterly dying to play Shelter 2 for ages as it looks awesome, but i am far too tight to pay the full price so i have been waiting for it to go on sale. It hasn't yet, but this one did today and while i am not as interested in Badgers as a Lynx, i coughed up the money and bought it.And i actually regret it....It wasn't a bad game by any means, it was just not a lot of game for my money, even at half price. There is very little in the way of a tutorial and the beginning of the game was rather confusing, as half the time it doesn't tell you what to do. But i started with five lovely cubs- after eventually figuring out that i had to feed one of them at the start to carry on in the game. And to start with it's a nice game. Feeding five cubs is actually rather demanding and i searched for food all the time. Though catching the Foxes is really hard. I only caught one and i never caught a frog at all. xD And keeping your cubs safe from the evil birds and wolves was quite fun and challenging, on my first play through.  I lost four and only managed to get one to the end. :( And the ending, wow. Not what i was expecting at all and personally i don't like it. But for £3 something this game doesn't have a lot in it and for full price it's certainly not worth it.1) You pretty much just walk in a predetermined direction, while picking up food and feeding your cubs, while trying (and failing) to avoid getting them killed.2) And there are only 5 levels, which took me just over an hour to get through and that's with replaying the last one.3) It does have some replay value, as i will try and get all five cubs to the end, but once i have done that, it will probably just sit in my library gathering dust.Which is unfortunate really, as this game could be much more. There are not nearly enough animal simulation games out there. So in the end, it's not a bad game and i was rather gutted when i lost each one of my cubs, it's just not much of a game and i would therefore sorta recommend it, but only at half price or more preferably. (I will put not recommended though, as i just think it's too expensive for what it is.)

												It's such a nice idea and so aesthetically pleasing, but the reality of playing it is just frustration. Because there's no UI in the name of immersion, you're constantly left wondering what it is the game wants you to do. For example, at the very beginning, you're in a cave with four live pups and one I assumed to be dead. I wandered around the cave and kept trying to exit but repeatedly hit an invisible wall, utterly confused as to what I was supposed to be doing. Eventually I figured out you're supposed to feet a plant to this "dead" pup to revive it. This would have been far more obvious if they had just given the pup a breathing animation or if it had made pathetic whining noises or something, making it obvious it was in fact alive. The tutorial is mysteriously patchy and explains little. Certain commands are never introduced in the tutorial, like the bark and the crouch. You have to turn to internet forums to get an explanation as to what they do, or even that they exist. During the nighttime section, the dash command mysteriously disappears for no apparent reason, only to reappear at odd times that seem to have to do with a predator? I lost two pups during this section and I don't even understand what I was supposed to do. What's really boggling is that there are little visual tutorials for other tasks, but not for this section, so you're left completely unsure of what you're supposed to do or what even happened. Maybe this was supposed to be for mood, but it just made me annoyed at the game.Another frustration is the lack of cursor - doubtless done for immersion, but it causes endless frustration when you're trying to target pups to feed. I ended up picking up and dropping food four or five times each time before I managed to feed the pup I intended to. The umpteenth time you have failed to target something, it gets annoying.And the most grating thing of all was the constant blocking of the camera by the background elements. Is transparency that hard to implement?It's a really nice and atmospheric idea that was ruined by frustrating mechanics. I couldn't get into the game because I felt like I just spent the whole time trying to figure out what the stupid game wanted me to do as I dropped turnips over and over. An hour in, I had lost 3/5 pups and realized I wanted the other two to just die so I could stop dealing with them. At this point, I quit. The frustration of the mechanics prevents you from getting attached to the pups at all, which is seemingly the point, here.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 14, 2013
												I have never played anything quite like Shelter.  Visually stunning, and emotionally resonant, this is one of the most memorable games I've played in quite a while.  It's the sort of game you have to experience for yourself to truly appreciate.Throughout the gorgeous landcapes, death is everywhere.  Your cubs don't have the experience you do; all they know is that you, their mother, will protect them.  But you are just a speck in the vast outdoors, and nature doesn't care about your pitiful pleas for mercy.This game is what indie games are all about (for me). Totally breaks the mold of what a traditional game should be about, look like, or play like. It's certainly not for everyone, but everyone should still play it. Such a beautiful, artistic gem. I enjoyed this game immensely.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2014
												Well, it's......uh... a very simple game actually. I liked in the beginning because I thought I could walk around... it has an interesting art style, though the gamma levels are too much. But most of the game is too linear and scripted for me to want to replay any part, and the controls feel clunky. It's not really fun or deep or that interesting. I dislike the ending, and it's a really really short game. They should have worked on this way more before releasing.Also I've been a badger mother before and this doesn't quite do it justiceEdit: there is also a "nurture mode" which I thought could be an alternative to some of the game's flaws... but no. You have to play it everyday (!!! this is a ridiculous mechanic), I was on day 5, then missed 2 days... suddenly it said "day 15" and all my babies were dead. Game over. There is no freedom, no way out of the game's restrictions, instead of relaxing or reflective it felt pointless and frustrating.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												I tried to like this game. I really did. But I think it's really terrible. The gameplay mechanics are minimal, you are mostly just playing four-legged walking/running simulator. The art style is garish and incredible desaturated to the point where I can't tell what the heck is going on. It was painstakingly slow waiting for my little badger to run to the next area. There was one point where it seemed clear I needed to run into a little cave but the game forced my badger to turn around and not go in. No explanation. I hate that kind of crap in games. This game doesn't respect my time at all. I know it's trying to be all artsy and get across some kind of emotional message, but for me I was so annoyed with the bad gameplay there was no chance to make any sort of connection. It is a cute idea, and the little badgers are cute, but this just seems like lazy and terrible execution on that idea. I'm sad because I can tell a lot of people love this game, but I just don't get it. Sorry!

number of helpful: 10 of 20 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												When I first heard of this game, I thought it'd be in line with pretty much all the other "survival" games out there: hunt food, avoid stuff you can't kill, and above all, STAY ALIVE. But boy was I ever wrong... I've never, never ONCE, been one to scorn people (read: game developers) for taking a different approach than the "standard average", but I think it's time to break that streak now. This game had an interesting concept, but it completely failed to deliver on pretty much every single point possible (and some I didn't even think it WAS possible to fail at, too!)First, we've got the issue of the controls. They're simple enough, sure... but you don't really have any actual CONTROL over things. Least of all your rather rëtarded little cubs. They run around rampantly, stealing food from their starving siblings, and of course, at the worst of times, they follow their dear mother, i.e. the player. For me, this ended with two being killed by predators, and a third to die by starvation (though not in that order exactly).Then, we've got the rather extreme issue of orientation. There's absolutely no way to know where you're supposed to go, what you're supposed to do, or hell, even what you're NOT supposed to do. There's nothing worth mentioning in terms of a tutorial, so once you've started playing, you're pretty much left completely clueless as to what to do and when, in order to keep your mentally underdeveloped offspring alive.Next up, we've got the horrifying graphics. I appreciate funky visuals, don't get me wrong, as I focking LOVED Child of Eden for it's colourful style, and I'm a HUGE fan of the pleasantly vibrant style that Bastion has. Aquaria made me have an eyegasm from its gorgeous graphics. But Shelter? It failed to deliver even a nudge, when I expected a whammy. The colours were so horribly watered out and pale that it was a tremendously underwhelming experience, seeing the game itself, and the brightness was so horrifyingly high that even if I'd completely RUIN my monitor's settings just for this game's sake, it STILL wouldn't be worth it.Following up the last one, we've got that "emotionally instigating sound" the developers are boasting so proudly of. Maybe I've been spoiled with such intense soundtracks as the original Lord of the Rings trilogy's OST, or hell, even the TRON: Legacy music, both of which were awe-inspiring to say the least, but Shelter's sound and music just felt jagged, stale and unstimulating.And last but not least, an issue among games I've been able to cope with since the dawn of my gaming life at the tender age of three... LENGTH. I found Beyond Good & Evil to be pleasantly bite-sized, and basically every CoD-game ever made to be decently lengthy, considering how they've essentially been 99% MP-oriented since installment #4, but Shelter was so infuriatingly short that I didn't feel satisfied at all. Granted, I didn't pay even half the game's, ahem... "actual value" (*mock-cough* BÜLLSHÏT!) since I bought it during the 2013 christmas sale, but even for the low price of 2,24€ it felt lacking and mind-numbingly short. Honestly, I was mad at whatever shïtheads that anally excreted Blue Shift for making such a horrifyingly short game, but you know what? Whoever you guys are, I forgive you. At least you TRIED. At least you provided MORE than a single hour's worth of "gameplay". Maybe not by much... but at least you TRIED. Shelter, however, is originally priced at a whopping 14€ for barely more than an hour's worth of gaming, which is even MORE than what you'll give for games such as Shadow Complex, Castle Crashers or hell, even Magicka, all of which provide (by comparison) infinite amounts of replayability and content.All in all, Shelter was without a doubt the biggest gaming blunder of not just 2013, but probably the whole decade. I've seen some bad games out there, like Big Rigs or Nation Red, but most of the games that are bad are that way 'cause of bugs, glitches, imbalanced gameplay, but with Shelter, the fault isn't with the game itself. It's that the developers (a pox on you all) didn't even TRY to deliver anything more than an interactive motion picture at such a ridiculously overdone price that it makes the BluRay copies of Ghibli-flicks seem "fair".I give this game the lowest rating I've ever given any game ever, and hopefully, it'll remain the ONLY game I'll ever review that I'll give this low of a score to as well... 0.0/10

												While I did enjoy the story and the graphics were very very interesting and amazing (in their own artistic way)... there wasn't much to the game.  It felt a bit misleading to what the game would be about.... which really is walking through enviroments trying to keep your babies alive... only to be met with your own fate at the end... yeah.. spoiler... but you might as well know it now before buying this game.I did enjoy it... and would recommend people to play it, but I wouldn't recommend it for anything more than Free to Play (or when it's on sale... as it is as of this review).There's just about 0 replayability to the game, and while that's not /terrible/ .... it certainly isn't worth very much to buy a game that takes, for me, just over an hour to play, only to be met with nothing different on another iteration of the game.  I commend the developers, ten-fold, for the game, as it really does have a high sense of artistic creativity stuffed in such a quick game, but must ask that in future updates, possibly have more of a RND aspect to the events therein.  At least some new aspects or areas... or expand the game a littlle more than it's at.Otherwise... there's 0 gripes about this fabulous work of artistry!

content:
Posted: June 9, 2015
AUDIOAtmosphericVISUALArtsyDIFFICULTYEasyVIBEEyecandyCRAVINGExperimentalON SALEFrequentlyPROS: The crumpley paper-mache look throughout the whole game is very beautiful. The colors in this game are superb and transition well. It is a very emotive experience.CONS: Often, it's poorly conveyed as to what you're to do or where you're to go. Gaming has come up with very small touches like artistic highlighting or proper camera use to push the player in the right direction while avoiding damages to the aesthetic, but Shelter utilizes few of them. The game also happens upon severe crashes for both me and my friend. Reinstallation did not help for either of us.WORTH: This game goes on sale very frequently, almost monthly. I couldn't get it to work, but being able to get it and try it out for only $1.50 USD is a great price. Steam has also implemented refunds since this review was written, so you can get your money back if you have similar trouble!OVERALL: I want to be able to finish this game, but have been unable to because of the constant crashing. My friend whom I had bought this for is on a completely different system and is dealing with similar crashes. These seem to be problems only some are dealing with. I'm NOT warning you against purchasing this game since not many people are dealing with this, only informing you of my experience.SCORE: 4/10                                                                     Full Review Coming Soon

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												I bought this game because the premise was simple and from the video, the style was very neat - in a sense that it was interesting. It is, by far, 'neat'. While the game is fun, I had to change the controls to something more.. easily accessable. It took a little bit to figure out what to do, since it just throws you into the game. First, I gotta say I love the models for the badgers and foxes. They're widdle and adorable. The noises and music are really nice, too. The second level gives you the 'creepy mood' without being over powering.The textures are very... messy. Tiling textures can be a pain, but looking at textures sloppily added onto the objects is also a pain - on the eyes. The textures are nice, but since nothing seems to tile, it just looks like a big, unfinished mess to me. The grass patches are obvious squares that go in alternating directions. It wouldn't take too long to easily make the textures they have tile, becuase they are already quite simple; full ambient, no shading. It is unique in it's own little style, though. You quicky get over it and enjoy the game. I think at first I just found it rather jarring.  I think my biggest pet peeve is the sky at night. Would it really be so hard to add glowing dots rather than what they have?? It looked like the cieling to a children's bedroom.The camera seems to get weird during some places, and it doesn't matter if it's close up or far away. Sometimes it just... does a weird 'thing'. Turns itself around? Suddenly too sensitive? It's hard to explain, but it's super prominent in the second level, which was hard to explore. The levels aren't linear - which is usually a good thing - but I find it easy to get lost, only being able to know where I've been from the holes of wild growing.. turnips? I thought they were potted plants, at first. Hehe.Anyway. The game is simple; maybe too simple. It's still fun, and I feel really bad for losing 2 cubs on the second level! If the textures tiled nicely, and didn't look like they were done in 10 minutes, this would be an awesome little game. It's easy to get attatched to your cubs once you figure out what you have to do, which can take a while to notice. From a distance, the environments are kinda pretty~ 10$ is actually quite a lot considering, so I'm glad I got it for $2.50.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												An interesting experiment is what I would call this game, but overall it fails to provide a reason to pay $10 (at the time of this review without discount). The game places you in the feet of a mother badger who must direct her cubs through different perils until they reach shelter. These perils consist of starvation, hawks, fire, water rapids, and unessen creatures of the night.The gameplay consists of guiding your badgers and trying to keep them fed by finding various food around the world, or by hunting down live animals like frogs or rats. Most of the time though the game is a giant escort mission where you make sure your badgerlings aren't carried off by a hawk or rapid by stealthily running from cover to cover and hoping your children follow.The game is also very short consisting of 6 or so levels which only round out about an hour of gameplay. There is a little replayability but it is possible to lose children along the way and continue the game, so reaching the end with all 5 children intact could extend your time with the game if you so wanted.The graphics look a bit like papercraft which gives the game a very unique style and can produce some beautiful scenery. Sometimes though there is a sort of white wash that is very noticibly placed over everything which really hurts the vibrant aspect of the world.With all of this said I can not recommend this game

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												I bought this game because the premise was simple and from the video, the style was very neat - in a sense that it was interesting. It is, by far, 'neat'. While the game is fun, I had to change the controls to something more.. easily accessable. It took a little bit to figure out what to do, since it just throws you into the game. First, I gotta say I love the models for the badgers and foxes. They're widdle and adorable. The noises and music are really nice, too. The second level gives you the 'creepy mood' without being over powering.The textures are very... messy. Tiling textures can be a pain, but looking at textures sloppily added onto the objects is also a pain - on the eyes. The textures are nice, but since nothing seems to tile, it just looks like a big, unfinished mess to me. The grass patches are obvious squares that go in alternating directions. It wouldn't take too long to easily make the textures they have tile, becuase they are already quite simple; full ambient, no shading. It is unique in it's own little style, though. You quicky get over it and enjoy the game. I think at first I just found it rather jarring.  I think my biggest pet peeve is the sky at night. Would it really be so hard to add glowing dots rather than what they have?? It looked like the cieling to a children's bedroom.The camera seems to get weird during some places, and it doesn't matter if it's close up or far away. Sometimes it just... does a weird 'thing'. Turns itself around? Suddenly too sensitive? It's hard to explain, but it's super prominent in the second level, which was hard to explore. The levels aren't linear - which is usually a good thing - but I find it easy to get lost, only being able to know where I've been from the holes of wild growing.. turnips? I thought they were potted plants, at first. Hehe.Anyway. The game is simple; maybe too simple. It's still fun, and I feel really bad for losing 2 cubs on the second level! If the textures tiled nicely, and didn't look like they were done in 10 minutes, this would be an awesome little game. It's easy to get attatched to your cubs once you figure out what you have to do, which can take a while to notice. From a distance, the environments are kinda pretty~ 10$ is actually quite a lot considering, so I'm glad I got it for $2.50.

												At the very beginning of the game you are not allowed to leave the burrow until feeding the "starving baby" that looks like a rock, but the tutorial on what to do in-game doesn't show up until after you can leave the burrow. I didn't lose them to the eagle, and I didn't lose them when we got hit by a wave; they were just suddenly gone and never came back.I tried nurture mode, but once again had to visit the forum because there's no in-game explaination that this mode is partially based in real time.  On day one, apparently all that can be done is bring two apples back to the burrow.  In order to do more, I need to come back another real life day, which seems unlikely at this point.I like the art, and the slow pace could have been a nice change, but in the end I can't help but feel that nothing I did in the last hour mattered much at all.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												Pointless walking simulator. So basically this game is just wandering around doing absolutely nothing except feeding your cubs, dodging a bird, and walking around. It looked pretty good in the trailers, but it's actually just plain boring. I bought this thinking it was a game where you can explore wherever you want, but you're actually on a set path. This game is barely worth the $2 I payed for it on sale, and you'd have to be crazy to pay $10 for it. One of the reasons I purchased Shelter was because of how nice the graphics looked, but once I started playing, I realized they weren't as good as they seemed. You can barely read the title screen because everything blends in with the background. Everything is really lightly colored. Nothing looks very realistic, and everything is made out of shapes. This game is not worth buying. Maybe it would be if it looked truly realistic, you could jump, fall off ledges, etc. I honestly don't know why this recieves so many good reviews. People say the game brings them to tears. People say the game is cute. People say the game is fun. They're wrong. If you want a good game for $10, go buy Undertale, it's so much better.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												This game has been on my wishlist for ages and I only wished I had picked it up earlier. 


YouTube™ Video: ➜ A Quick Look @ 'Shelter' 

			Views: 27		

			LOVE MUSIC? - GRAB SOME GREAT MUSIC HERE: http://paradisedecay.bandcamp.com/ Massive Thanks to the Dev's for the Steam Review Copy!		

In Shelter you get to experience the wild as a mother badger sheltering her cubs from harm. On their journey they get stalked by a bird of prey, encounter perils of the night, river rapids crossings, big forest fires and the looming threat of death by starvation. Food is to be found, but is there enough for everyone? You will learn that the cubs need food not just to survive, but to enable them overcome the varying challenges they will face as they make their way through the world. The question in the end is who will survive to live another day?  - Recommended!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Shelter, or as I like to call it "The Badger Game" is a potentially PTSD-invoking first person badger game. You play the part of a single mother badger, desperately trying to lead your helpless badgerlings to safety. Not only do you have to feed the little guys, but you must navagate perils such as swooping raptors and road-kill hungry carnivores with a penchant for badger flesh. At least - I think there are cars eventually, but I don't *actually* have first hand experience with them so they may not actually exists. If they *do* actually exist the drivers may or may not actually intend to hit and/or kill the critters. I can't with a good conscious recommend this game because of the psychological trauma that I endured after one of my baby badgers, Two Stripes, was swooped up and carried off by an eagle within twenty minutes of starting the game. I found myself falling into a swirling pit of despair, shouting "MY BABY! MY BABY!" It was all for naught, Two Stripes was lost forever. I have yet to resume the game.Or, if you want to support an indie game about badgers, go for it. In fact, go for it.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Not a bad game, but too little content for that price tag. If you buy this in 50+% discount, maybe.I liked the "story". The mechanics were too simple, I hoped for something a bit more complex. The graphics is artistic, I didn't particularly like it, but I don't object too much. The game is certainly not well optimized, sometimes the framerate dropped even with a high-end machine.The thing I disliked the most is the camera. It's a freaking disaster. If you create a badger simulation, where you constantly travel through forest half a meter above ground at most, you must not block the view every time there is a tree. foliage or a boulder between you and the badger. This game does that, and even worse. Often your view is actually inside the rock, tree or bush. You can either zoom in as much as you can to the badger, have zero outlook but not blocked your view much, or zoom out, have great outlook, but blocked your view 50% of the time. I believe camera is really the reason why not recommend this game, that's how bad it is. So sad. "Fortunately" the game is not long (an hour), so you'll not suffer for long.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2016
												Do you like playing games on a laptop out in the sun? Then you'll love this game. Through the miracle of bad art design, this game will make you feel just like it even when playing in a dark room! This game also manages to both annoy me for the lack of tutorials and annoy me for exesive use of tutorials. You start off in a burrow as a badger where you can walk around with your badger-kids following you. As you explore you'll find some rocks, some sort of beetroot and an exit with an invisible wall. After reading a walkthroug i found out that one of the rocks is actually one of your hungry badger-kids. This was so obvious that the developers decided to not include any hint or tutorial. After that is done the invisible wall is suddenly gone when you try to exit once again. As you walk throgh the narrow passage, your camera will clip through much of the terrain and hanging roots. When you finally get out of the contrastless booring darkness, what should have been a cool contrast between the darkness of the cave and the refreshing light cast by the sun, is instead more grey eye-straining fullbright. You are immediately taunted buy several tutorials saying: - "Oh you were smart enough to get out of the cave? Better remind you that you should gather food with the use key!" and - "This tree has a bright red apple in it. It's really easy to see as all the other colors are grey. Any idiot could probably realize that you can sprint into it so that the apple falls down, but we are going to spoil that for you anyway."After that there is more gathering of food through a forest closed on both sides. How hungry are the badger-kids? There is so much food that you don't really have the time to find out because you'll soon lose any interest in the game. Im sure there's more beyond that point, but it was too long until the next step so I just stopped after a while. 1/10, overpraised linear casual game with interesting art style, destroyed by it's horrible low contrast and high brightness setting.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Not a bad game, but too little content for that price tag. If you buy this in 50+% discount, maybe.I liked the "story". The mechanics were too simple, I hoped for something a bit more complex. The graphics is artistic, I didn't particularly like it, but I don't object too much. The game is certainly not well optimized, sometimes the framerate dropped even with a high-end machine.The thing I disliked the most is the camera. It's a freaking disaster. If you create a badger simulation, where you constantly travel through forest half a meter above ground at most, you must not block the view every time there is a tree. foliage or a boulder between you and the badger. This game does that, and even worse. Often your view is actually inside the rock, tree or bush. You can either zoom in as much as you can to the badger, have zero outlook but not blocked your view much, or zoom out, have great outlook, but blocked your view 50% of the time. I believe camera is really the reason why not recommend this game, that's how bad it is. So sad. "Fortunately" the game is not long (an hour), so you'll not suffer for long.
