number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												Hmm, who would have thought something like this could work out so well? A game about a mother badger feeding and protecting her cubs from the dangerous wildnerness that constantly keeps you on your toes.The game consists of 5 levels, each one with a unique theme, the first being a sort of calmer, introductory level to teach players the mechanics of the game (feeding, hunting and hiding), quickly moving on to the scary Night time, an hostile environment that easily scares the cubs, having them running into the predator's den. Then, you'll deal with a rainny day, traversing through overflowing rivers that might just drown you if you're not careful, after that leading to a Fiery forest, trying to keep the flames at bay. All this while trying not to be caught by an eagle, the "antagonist" of this game (or is it?), concluding everything in the last level, a constant hide and seek between the two species.This was an unexpected game, with a unique graphic style, and very beautifully done! The game brings a feeling of persistent consequence everytime a cub is lost, since there is no going back after one has been killed. As a result, you're constantly on your toes, and, despite its limited length, it's totally worth the time and money. There's the possibility of multiple playthroughs, trying to save as many cubs as possible.Overall a very positive experience, which I'll go through at least once again to see how different it is after a good grasp of the  ways of surviving. I'd advise anyone looking for something different to play it.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												It was very easy to find food, but the sense of loss and danger keep you on your toes.  The game pulls at you emotionally, but unfortunately fails to expound very much upon the mechanics it establishes. For instance, none of my cubs ever became hungry enough to fall sick which could have added the challenge of leaving a cub behind and keeping the others safe while trying to find food. Although the game begins with a sick cub, this idea is not once revisited.Overall, the game is wonderfully made and thoughtfully put together. I definitely recommend playing this, but I wish the ideas were a little more fleshed out.  I don't know if I can say that the $10 price isn't worth it, but the game's 1hr length definitely brings it under question.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2015
												Shelter is an amazing game.You play as a mother badger, tasked with feeding and protecting your five cubs, as you travel the world filled with rich atmosphere. A lot of your time is spent running around, locating or reaching food, and avoiding dangers not for yourself but for your vulnerable pups. The only real defense you have against the natural predators that stalk your pups is stealth, size, and determination. You WILL lose one of your babies, and you will be forced to move on immediately for the sake of the rest of your pups.This game has a lot of atmosphere and beauty to it. The type of game that you play for the experience. Sometimes it can be slow, or tedious, and at times it can also feel like a linear path which can take away from the world that is built around you. But it's far too easy to become immersed, to name your individual pups only to realize that your favorte one had gotten swept away by a bird of prey or by the powerful river. The repetition of survival feels present with each life.For anyone that enjoys an immersive, beautiful-looking and beautiful-sounding game, Shelter is for you. If you happen to also enjoy a dash of nature and is fascinated by the cruel challenges of wildlife, then this game delivers.However, if you need a game to have stimulating and exciting gameplay, and do not care for the idea of animal-sim games, then take extra consideration before purchasing this game. I will say that, for it's humble price, it has plenty to offer right off the bat.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												Shelter is a unique little game where you play as a female badger who must protect her offspring as they journey with her throughout the game's world, which consists of forests, mountains and rivers. You must feed your babies regularly or else they will starve - there are plenty of food items around the world, which is useful, however during more intense moments you'll need to make sure that your offspring aren't going hungry as you spend your time trying to reach a safer area.Dangers in the world come from other animals such as hawks as well as factors in the environment such as rushing water. These provide the player with a lot of challenge, especially if they want to keep all of their babies alive. Whilst the babies are cute, their AI isn't perfect, and on several life or death situations I've had them prance around a turnip instead of following me to safety. There are also a few glitches with falling fruit, where it falls on top of a baby badger, it will cause the baby to freeze up. This can be solved easily however.The music and environments are very beautifully-designed, and look like they've just come out of a book. I did encounter a few FPS drops, however, which seemed strange as I have a very powerful PC. The game's soundtrack is also wonderful, and it will also change in composition depending on what action is unfolding on screen, which is very effective, especially during the more tense parts of the game.My main gripes Shelter are probably the mentioned issues, along with the game itself which is a tad on the short side. However, there is also a nurture mode which I've not played yet, which has a much longer replay value and is a sort of tamagotchi-like mode where you must feed your offspring every real-life day.Overall, I think Shelter is a great little game, and a good example of a unique game concept that works well.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												A survival game about a mother badger trying to keep her cubs alive while wandering through the forest. Many dangers lay ahead, including evil birds, wild rivers and starvation. Being a badger is not all sunshines and rainbows, I can tell you that.The graphics in 'Shelter' are not bad and original but personally I thought they were a little on the bright side. The gameplay is mostly about running and hiding from other creatures and make sure your cubs make it aswell. You can give your cubs food you find but that's about it. Sometimes when you've been running from danger you'll notice one (or more) of your cubs is missing. In my opinion this part could be a little more dramatic, which may be unrealistic but personally I did not really feel bad for getting them killed. Overall Shelter is an OK and short game. It's not bad but to me it felt like it could be way more than it is now.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												NOTE: I actually do recommend this game, if you're a fan of SHORT, indie, minimalist games. I value my experience at about $1, and I wouldn't recommend paying more than that. I finished the game in just under an hour.Shelter was short so I'll try to be too. You're a parent badger and you need to get your 5 cubs to safety. You will forage for food and avoid predators and other dangers along the way. How many babies can you get to the finish? Shelter has a low-poly minimalist style, and I think this is a detriment to the game. What is food doing? Does it help? How much? How urgent is it versus rushing past everything? The game didn't communicate this. The game occurs over 4 medium-ish sized levels.With so little to talk about, because there's so little to the game, I was expecting more emotion in the experience, and it didn't really do it for me. Moral of the story: Nature is harsh, so pump out those babies, everyone!

number of helpful: 12 of 26 people (46%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												Time for an honest review.I saw Shelter 2 coming out, and saw this for cheap and went "Heck yeah, I want that!"This game is nothing like the name, nor Shelter 2 would imply. There is no shelter. You do not return to a shelter every night (or day, if you're a nocturnal animal). You never do anything but walk and grab food for most of the game. Your cubs don't get hungry, food just makes them ever-so-slightly bigger every time they eat. Okay, you might think, hey, at least you can forage where you want. Nope. This is not an open world game. This is a "follow the tiny corridors" and "find where the developer wants me to go" game while picking up random fruit along the way. This is a platformer collect-the-coins but with no jumping... or platforms.Then you get to areas with eagles hunting you, dashing between cover, and that is fun the first time! It is repetitive afterward. Then you hit water streams that FOR NO REASON WHATSOEVER either periodically send waves killing your babies, OR, randomly send waves if you stand on the water too long. With ZERO warning and ZERO instruction, you lose your babies. This just in: Rivers don't have gigantic waves. It's not the ocean.I was down to 2 of my 5 cubs by the end of the game and every single one that died was from some complete B.S. like a cub getting stuck, or not having enough time to cross a stream.The fact the game disables the "run" ability all the time, including the intro, makes it feel like it's preaching at you even though you it never says a word the whole time. It's like it forces you to bask in how much pride the developers take in their game. The game has good traits. But the problems I mentioned basically sap the fun back out and leaves you wondering... "What that it?" I applaud these guys for doing what they did. But you basically have to REALLY REALLY be wishing for this exact type of game to enjoy it, and if you expected different from the videos, well... you'll be disappointed.Lastly, replayability... there is none. There's nothing to do once you beat the game except try it all over again but without any of the surprises you had.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												68 minutes. Lost 2 guys, none of which I knew why or how (1 in the dark apparently, because they got randomly spooked and they scattered and 1 must have been out of sight too long, and the other to the bird, while I had no indicator on the ground where it even was...eh).   Anyway, I would not recommend the game for full price. Maybe 1-2 bucks. It's just too short. It's got no real replay value. The tutorial and the HUD itself are vague as in in "almost not present". The 360 controller is now supported, although you can neither rebind those buttons nor does the tutorial show them...they only show the keyboard commands.The game itself is fairly short as you've probably guessed now. Your missions is to guide 5 baby badgers to safety. Great that the game starts you off with "saving" 1 of your guys from starving...without telling you that a) he is starving (could also be dead for all I know) or b) how to save him (which brings us to c) where to find food and d) how to get said food and feed it to your young). I've worked it out eventually. You will, too, but it's unnecessary, especially since the game will show you how to gather food AFTER you have already had to do it. Bloody stupid. So, your guys need to stay well fed...apparently the greyer they get the hungrier they are. Apart from that you can also hunt some animals, though not necessary...you can be a vegan in this game and you have to brave some dangers, one of them the frequently returning and annoying hawk, the rest being the night (a whole level), fire (another level) and water (again, another level). All of those require ducking and running basically.   The game really isn't all that difficult, but you can't save. It's supposed to make you care for your young, but I found that rather hard. Meh, it's an "interesting" game and it deserves credit for what it does and its art style. It is NOT a bad game, it just isn't worth a lot of money in my opinion.

												This has to be one of of the worst games, if not the worst game, I have ever played. More boring than church as a child with your single mother and sister at 7am surrounded by crippled, hunched, octogenarians wheezing some 470 year old verse about wheat, sneering at you for not yet drowning in the throes of senility.The artstyle is a novelty that fails to carry or excuse the repetitive drone of the music, the sickeningly pathetic AI of your children, the shocking pathing of both your cubs and the supposed 'fodder' frogs foxes rats etc. which are utterly inconsequential and you don't need because there's ♥♥♥♥ing turnips everywhere, and by far the awful, AWFUL linear, and when I mean linear.. Draw a ♥♥♥♥ing line on your table, see that line - THAT'S THE GAME, linear playstyle. Pitifully short, actually not emotional at all, despite what you may expect as a result of the 7 year old girls who's fathers are trying to get them into gaming or explain the cold brutality of life, who have played this game and comment 'AWWWWW BUH SUH CUTE AND SAD' because the stupidity of your cubs is only matched by the impossibly infuriating implacability of your relentless, pathetically programmed, enemies ie, THAT INESCAPABLE ♥♥♥♥ING EAGLE.. Swear the next ♥♥♥♥ing bird I see I'm gonna KILL IT.. and by the time I finished with one ravenous, gimp brained ♥♥♥♥wit of a badgerbaby I couldn't care less about the 'beyond ridiculous' fashion in which I had lost the others. Don't waste your money, even on sale.. This worthless, laughable ♥♥♥♥ing mistake isn't worth $1Have yet to play the sequel.. If it's the same unimaginative, confining, agitating waste of time.. I'm hunting these ♥♥♥♥ing devs down.

												Without spoiling the game, (I'll do that later) let's just say you are forced to do something you work really hard to prevent.  Then BAM!  That moment really sucked!   I don't really recommend the game just for that one forced event alone...  BUT, the biggest pain is having to constantly worry about getting food for your freakishly hungry cubs!!!  That is the whole game!  Digging up roots and bumping trees with your head to get apples to drop.  Once I got to kill a rat to feed one of my cubs.  Boring game!!!  Again, I don't recommend this game...  Maybe I should have played it longer, but that one forced event made me depressed!!!(SPOILER ALERT!) Dev's... You should really have made the game so you could save all the cubs...  You should not have to leave one behind to die of starvation!  Lame move!  And what's up with having to constantly feed them!  Not realistic at all!  Bummer.  I was looking forward to this game being fun, not depressing and at times frustrating…Here are my system specifications: Apple iMac, i5 Quad-Core Intel processor 3.1GHZ, AMD Radeon HD 6970M with 1GB dedicated video RAM, 4GB system RAM, 1TB hard drive running OS X version 10.6.8, Journaled HFS+ Extended file system.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Shelter is a beutifull game, but is it a game you want to play ? In Shelter you play as a Mother Badger to get baby badgers to get some food, but when something happens it becomes a fight for survival. So how is Shelter ? Its a pretty good game. This game is pretty simple all you do is walk around and try to protect youre baby badgers from the lurking dangers. Its a really simple game it couldnt get more simple then Shelter. Now the art style is the most beutifull youll see this year it really delivers an amazing art style that will leave you breathless. The game is pretty short only an hour long but thats not neccesaseraly a bad thing its pretty much the right lenght for this kinda game. Overall you have an amazing game with a fantastic art style, simple gameplay. The only kinda problem i found in this game is sometimes there are texture pop in's and the baby badger might get themselfs killed when they dont follow you. Overall i give this game an 8/10

												It's hard for me to dislike any video game. ACtually I'm not sure there even is one I dislike? however I must say that  I played this game for about 20 minutes, and there is no option to save. When I went back to it, I had to start again, and the first run through was so zzzzz that I didn't actually want to play again. Well... to be fair, nothing happens unless you like pressing left mouse button to make your badger squeak a bit. oh and the baby ones squeak back at you too afterwards which is so rewarding if you like squeaking badgers. Other than squeaking and picking up strange fruit which look like origami from Heavy Rains child killer, you spend most of your time walking your badger. It is fun for a whole 2.4 seconds and then it gets a bit tedious. Imagine having sex with your mothers sofa. (not based on experience) so really if you like squeaking, walking badger simulations, this is your game, just be prepared for loading it up a 2nd time, and all the walking you did, may need to be redone. I wish there was a car or something so I could have run myself over, maybe there was, but I never got that far before falling asleep n headbutting my glass of milk...

content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												I really, really wanted to love this game. But alas, I actually hated my entire experience with it...I went straight in to "New Game" and had no clue about controls or what to do. It took a good ten minutes - inclusive of a YouTube play-through viewing - to realise the controls. Already I am disliking the amount of time and effort just to get out of my blasted cave...Atop this is the appaling camera. I am aware that this is an independent game and that "auto" camera is unlikely, but the manual nature of it is extremely irritating, given my constant (every few seconds, perhaps ten or fifteen seconds if I have been walking in a straight line for some time) need to adjust it. If you turn around, you will need to move the camera. If there is an object or scenery item near you, you will need to move the camera. It is that simple.Then there are the action controls. They are simple enough! One key to do some sort of action such as removing a plant from the ground or giving something to your babies. However, it almost never seems to blooming work! In particular, I was never able to interact with a fruit tree to make it drop its fruit for my babies, which means they will probably die of hunger soon... Alas, a wonderful concept, beautiful art and world, relaxing and immersive soundtrack... but let-down by OBYSMAL controls!.. I am hoping that the sequel will have better controls...

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												TRUE GEMLet me start form the end. It was long time since I cried and even longer since I cried because of PC game well I think I can without shame say that Shelter made me reset this counter. I expect nice little game with badgers and it is that indeed. BUT  on top of that (perhaps like bonus) I get bucket of emotions and emotional knock out on the end.Let's get to the game as it is. First that will hit you is graphic is unusual but very lovely in same time. You play as mother badger starting in your den with 5 little cubs and one of those need your help straight away as it is weak of starvation, So you get it food or leave it behind your choice. Following is long journey for you and your litter as you take them from the den and on way to safety of mountains where they can learn what it mean to be badger. On your long and tiresome journey you will encounter many obstacles like dark and wolves, hunting eagle (or hawk i cant really tell), crossing creek during heavy rain and at last (not least) the forest fire.But then your journey is finished and safety of mountain forest is front of you there is only last meadow to cross and last Eagle/hawk to avoid so you move on and......What happen then I will not tell to avoid spoilers I only say this, after all the stress and fright of loosing my cubs what happened tear down the last wall and I sat there 5 minutes in tears. When someone make game that can pull you in so much that it slowly scrubbing away all those invisible walls you build so you can deal with everyday♥♥♥♥♥♥of world out there THAT game is definitely deserve space on your HD.I am giving this 10/10 things that will make you feel like you are there and badgers this is game for you.

number of helpful: 10 of 27 people (37%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Experience the wild as a mother badger sheltering her cubs from harm. On their journey they get stalked by a bird of prey, encounter perils of the night, river rapids crossings, big forest fires and the looming threat of death by starvation.Food is to be found, but is there enough for everyone? You will learn that the cubs need food not just to survive, but to enable them overcome the varying challenges they will face as they make their way through the world.Are you ready for a truly different adventure, something that might evoke feelings you've never felt in a game before? In the wild, all living creatures are put to the test. The question in the end is who will survive to live another day?Retro Family have once again composed a beautiful soundtrack to an original and graphically innovative setting in a world of nature where shelter is your only hope and survival your only goal.

Posted: October 28, 2015
												Low poly games tend to have something special: the lack of high detailed graphics is filled with hard work in other features. That’s the case of Shelter.As it can be seen in the trailer, the main carácter is mother badger. She’s in charge of her five puppies (a strong, mature, independent mother indeed). Our task will be to lead and protect them from the dangers of the forest.The gameplay itself doesn’t shine much: charge into a tree to make its fruits fall to feed the puppies, hunt a little fox for meat, cross a river in a rainy day… Everything in order to protect the cute badgers. Althought i just said the mechanics are not spectacular, they have a much deeper purpouse: to make you realize how fragile your babies are. They are curious, fearful, and all they have to survive is you. Through this journey you will discover how savage the nature can become. Shelter itself is quite short for the full Price, but on sales is very worth. It’s a nice choice for those players who like to disconnect from every other game than relies on shooting and running all the time.Just a last tip that will help you in Shelter:Don’t name your babies. Just. Don’t.Because i miss Johny.

Posted: March 8
												     Let me tell you a story about a mother badger and her five ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ pups.  Donut, Leafy, Spikey, Eggplant, and Sideburns.  No matter how hard the mother tried, she couldn't save them from themselves.  Each was so stupid in their own right. Eggplant wouldn't eat, Spikey would eat too much, Donut couldn't keep up, Sideburns scared easily, and Leafy loved birds.  One by one, each of them fell.  Leafy stopped to look at an eagle, which then picked him up and dropped him onto a rock.  Spikey was so hungry he went full cannibal and ate Leafy's corpse.  This, of course, scared Sideburns, and he ran off into a river which swept him away never to be seen again.  The smart ones that were left ran with their mother, who tried her best to protect them.  Donut, fell victim to his own fatassness and died to a fox that was trailing them.  Eggplant, the last of them all, died of a broken heart and an empty stomach; for he missed his siblings and couldn't live without them.  The mother, with no purpose left, made it to her final destination, curled up into a ball, and died.liek if u cri erytiem

It is so hard to keep everyone alive and thats what happens in reality and I think this game has captured that perfectly. Although also like most games of this genre I dont think there is much replay value there, and I did get bored after a while, I still think Shelter ranks up there with other tear jerker indie titles.10/10 from me

Posted: April 9, 2014
												This is an incredibly short, but beautiful game. The colours are pale and chalky and the music and sounds are soft and relaxing. The art style of this game and cute and inspiring and the storyline is simple and realistic. There are no goals or missions so you have to use your instincts to figure out what to do, which I really like. It tells you what to do with simple graphics but doesn’t have too much information or text to distract you from the feeling this game give you.The controls are simple are you feel a strong bond with your young. Even though the game is very relaxing it can still cause your heart to skip a beat when your babies are in danger. There are many challenges to get past such as a mother eagle, creatures hidden in the shadows, a rapid, and a forest fire.In each level you have to check on your cubs to see if any of them are hungry and when you find food you have to choose which one to feed it to as you have to share to keep them all full and happy.Even though this game I very short, it’s not a game that you only really want to play the once. This game is so nice that you’ll want to come back for more and maybe keep on trying until you reach the end without losing any of your babies (a personal goal of mine I have yet to reach).When watching the trailer I was hesitant about buying it as it looked too challenging and not really my kind of game however I am so glad that I DID buy it, as it has now become one of my favourite games.	This game is simple enough so that children can play too (although not too young, as some parts are hard to get around).If there is one thing that I don’t particularly like about this game is the ending (which I won’t spoil) however I don’t think that it needs to be changed, just made less confusing as it made me wonder whether I did it wrong or not.In conclusion this game is perfect for anyone who wants something to pass the time, or enjoys a nice, relaxing, and sometimes challenging game.9.5/10

												Shelter is a beautiful game depicting the life of a mother badger. I love the art style, but the text is often unreadable (fortunately only menu text is important). I didn't see enough there to make fetch quests fun, but I didn't really give it a chance. Maybe later.

Posted: April 22, 2014
												Very cute game that plays strongly with the player's emotions. The objective of the game is to play the role of a badger mother tending to her cubs. You feed the cubs while progressing through the world and the various 'stages' and protecting them from hazard. Losing a cub leaves a feeling of loss and a failure as a badger mother.It's very tempting to speed through the game. This is a game that's meant to be enjoyed in moderation, for the sights and the overall feeling of attachment to the cubs. The scenery is beautiful, but a bit too bright/washed out. It gives it a consistent, calming, pastel colored, albeit polygonal world. If you do try the game, do try to stop and enjoy the surroundings. Highlights of the game include stage 2 (starry night/mother's light), feeling of loss upon losing a badger cub, and a well executed ending.It's a very short game, and a bit debatable as to whether 10$ is really the correct price point for it. The nurture mode is apparently modelled after a Tamagotchi style game and looks promising: if returning to the game daily to feed your cubs apples that you knock off from trees with your head and radishes you pluck from the ground is your thing.This isn't a Modern Warfare game. It's not meant to be graphically intensive, it doesn't have guns, and it's not overly realistic in the department of European Badger diets. It's not meant to be Badger Simulator 2013, though some would be eager to call it that. If the description above doesn't appeal to you, then don't bother.It's a casual, experimental game that's meant to be cute. You want to try this game if you're looking for something unique and are inclined to cute, casual games and prone to the emotional aspect.I love this game, but in all honesty, I might be biased... just a bit.

Posted: April 14, 2014
												Shelter คือเกมส์ Indie เกมส์นึงที่จะนำคุณไปสู่ชีวิตเจ้า Badger 6 ตัว แม่/พ่อ 1 ลูก 5 กับการผจญภัยที่ประสบภัยต่างๆ-Graphicทำออกมาได้ตาม Style เกมส์ Indie ดีอาจจะทำให้ปวดตาบางช่วงเพราะเรื่องสีเกมส์นี้กลมกลืนกันมาก-Gameplayสำหรับใครที่ขวัญอ่อน(แบบผม)ขี้กลัวจะสะดุ้งบ่อยหน่อยในเกมส์มีสัตว์ 3 ชนิด กบ จิ้งจอก เหยี่ยว(อันนี้ตกใจสุด) Controls น้อยเล่นได้ง่ายๆ-Storyสำหรับผมแล้วออกแนว Drama เพราะเห็นลูกตายทีไรผมรู้สึกว่าเป็นความผิดผมแล้วเห็นใจ พ่อ/แม่ว่ากว่าจะเลี้ยงมาได้ TT ในเกมส์แล้วจะมีทั้ง 5 ChaptersChapter 1 จะไม่มีไรมากเดินตามทางไปเรื่อยๆและหลบหนีเหยี่ยวในท้าย ChapterChapter 2 เป็นตอนกลางคืนก็ไม่ต่างไรมากเดินตามทางเดินไปเรื่อยChapter 3 เป็นพายุเข้าโดยจะให้เราเดินข้ามแม่นํ้าเยอะหน่อยChapter 4 เป็นตอนที่ป่าไหม้เราจะต้องเดินผ่านป่าที่ไหม้นั้นไปอีกฝั่งที่ปลอดภัยChapter 5 เป็นฉากสุดท้ายของเกมส์นี้โดยจะเดินไปเรื่อยๆแต่จะเจออุปสรรค์ 2 อย่าง จิ้งจอก กับ เหยี่ยวสำหรับใครที่ไม่รู้วิธีผ่านไปได้ที่ Guide ใน Steam น่ะครับเป็นภาษาอังกฤษไปแปลกันเอาเองขอขอบคุณที่มาอ่าน Review กันน่ะครับผิดพลาดตรงไหนบอกได้ครับ

Posted: August 27, 2014
												ART&MUSIC: The artistic quality of the game was one of my favorite aspects. The color remained vivd throughout, creating a different atmosphere than most. The rain had to be one of my favorites as red was everywhere (not the typical blue), and the music that matched -- abosultely stunning. CHARACTERS: Well, they are badgers. There's not much to them, but you certainly get attached. GAMEPLAY: I never ran into any problems...well, I did get lost a few times. However, that really made the game for me. Panicking, wondering where the 'mother' is supposed to go to next to get away from danger just added to the quality of the game. 8/10: It's short. I want to play through again and take the time to really make the badgers grow, but again it's REALLY short. What broke the game for me was the end result. Given that the game has such a 'dropoff' ending I would still recommend it for the music, art, and concept that it has to offer. Definitely can't wait for the second!

Posted: April 1, 2014
												The moment you are constantly turning your camera around to check on your pups: you'll know Shelter has reached its goal. Shelter is a thrilling, upsetting, and sadly short, journey about a mother badger taking care of her young. The game clearly puts a lot of thought into the life of being a parent, and it really pulls it off for the player. During my first playthrough of Shelter i lost one pup; although close to the end of the level, i ran back trying to find him/her and i felt awful. I could not find him/her or simply load a save: I had lost one of my children. Shelter immerses the player into the role of a parent amazingly well and it only drives you in deeper as you constantly feed and nurture your children in order for them to stay alive. I am surprised this title has not won an indie game award for its immersive atmosphere and beautiful environment; but nevertheless, it is still a treat: award or no award. If you're looking for an immersive atmosphere and a huge focus on captivating the player, then buy Shelter.

Posted: April 1, 2014
												A simple game baced around protecting 5 baby badgers that you lead around the forest and away from harm. For 5 AI that could potential screw up a game, they  follow your every comand, I've never encounterd a problem with them, litteraly flawless. They even sit down and wait there turn to be fed, if you give them 2 or 3 seconds go get oriented. All of the levels vary heavily so its never like your looking or playing the same thing, each level has a different challenge as well. The art style works in the games favor as well, even a net book could run it and looks great. The controls are easy to get used to and never put you at an unfair disadvantage. Easily the best part of the game is you feel bad when you let one of your cubs get out of sight or die. I felt my heart drop every time an of them died or even got out of my sight, there is a real drive to see them all live throughout the adventure. At the time of this review the game is only $2.50 and honestly its more than worth it. the adventures thrilling, the asthetics are nice and at the end you feel happy yet sad. Give shelter a try.

Posted: December 30, 2013
												Shelter is a survival game where you control a mother badger whose task is to take care of her cubs, feed them, and lead them to safety while protecting them from predators and other various threats. It's a short (~90 minutes) and linear game but very beautifully crafted and does a fine job of eliciting fear, sadness and joy as you make your journey. It's easy to get caught up in the experience and feel as though you're actually taking care of these cubs. That moment when a hawk swoops down and lifts away your child, or watching the rushing water carry them downstream, is surprisingly gut-wrenching. You feel as though you failed not just as someone playing a videogame but also as a parent to these virtual creatures.The game's visual style will probably be hit or miss with players. The blocky, pastel-colored design is unique and interesting, but the high brightness/gamma while playing can feel kinda strange. When I was done it took me a few minutes to re-adjust my eyes back to normal. The game also makes great use of audio cues and sound effects throughout to help make you feel more immersed in the nature setting. The camera work can be shoddy at times when near trees, rocks, walls, etc., but I didn't find it to be distracting enough to be a major concern.Overall, Shelter is a game that does a beautiful job of telling a story about the trials of parenting and the circle of life. A short yet emotionally powerful experience.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												The most distressing game I've played since Penumbra, Its like someone got around to making a video game based on watership down.  You have absolutely no stated goal, though in the first minute of the game its implied the purpose is to keep your cubs alive. Youll start by wandering around, picking up food for them (entirely because they eat it when you drop it - there is nothing telling you how hungry or full they are or need to be, and they never stop eating) then learn to hunt other animals juuuust before you are shown you can be hunted too. Youll need to apply what you learned from being the hunter to survive being the prey, the primary lesson being "Your cubs are loud and stupid, and youre just going to have to figure out how to work around that"Its one big stealth escort mission, but you wont mind it while you sit in silent horror as your cubs playfully trot out in the open while a hungry falcon flies overhead. It also doesnt help that the game is a looker, and the soundtrack calming.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Even though I feel like this game missed out on realizing its full thematic potential, I still found it more emotionally stirring and visually mesmerizing than many much bigger titles out there. Shelter toys with players' familiarity with game conventions and our notions of a control-success correlation by allowing randomness to factor into the cubs' survival. Although I think the developers did this to emphasize themes of survival-of-the-fittest and the inevitable losses of parenthood, it doesn't make for the most enjoyable gameplay experience. At just over an hour, Shelter is just the right length as it compresses and contextualizes these themes admirably, yet still fails to provide a compelling progression of gameplay mechanics. While I would have liked to have seen the game more fully fleshed-out, I still laud Might and Delight for tackling such unconventional subject matter within the medium.

Posted: January 3, 2016
												I don't get what other people were seeing in this. I don't hate it, I just don't recommend it to others. Shelter is a game where you are a mother badger escorting 5 smaller badgers to a different part of the forest. But Oh No! There are foxes, hawks, fires, floods, and more along the journey. The game begins with only 4 cubs and a grey one that appears dead on the floor. Without tutorial, you're supposed to know that to proceed you need to feed the baby badger a root. This never comes up again and it feels needless. After that, you proceed to learn how to get food (which you already did), how to hide, how to bark, and why you should hide. The problem is that's about it. The entire game is basically the tutorial portion repeated a few times. You'll find yourself in several hawk chase scenes and they just don't feel tense after the first one because its just the same scenerio over and over. The hawk squaks ever time you walk out of the grass, regardless of where it's shadow is and you "just" make it every time. My other problem with this game is that for a baby escort game, there's a lot of times where you'll find yourself saying "Why did my baby die this time?" Additionally, the gamma here is horrendous. Everything looks like your screen's blacklight is malfunctioning, but there's no way to change the visual settings. On top of that, there's a number of graphical glitches, such as floating trees and the camera constantly clipping or otherwise being annoying. I didn't even feel particularly sad when my baby badgers died because at first I thought it was scripted and since I'm not controling them, I have no ability to stop them from getting ?eaten by an owl? or swooped up by a hawk. For that reason, I don't even understand the "crying into a pillow" meme that litters the positive review section.

Posted: December 15, 2015
												9/10 A little gem. Beautiful art, simple but well-designed game mechanics. The chief merit of this game is how it challenges the typical narrative frames within which most games operate to provide a truly compelling--emotionally compelling--gaming experience. Sounds silly, but as a mother badger, you get very emotionally invested in keeping your little cubs alive. I've done my fair share of "escort quests" in MMO's, but this--whether because of how utterly dependent the cubs are or how unstoppable some of the predators are--really stirs your protective instincts. Not sure whether non-parent players will experience the same thing. That moment when you look behind you and you only see four cubs where there were five a moment ago is truly disheartening. I confess I didn't do so well on my first play-through (which took less than an hour). So I tried again, armed with my knowledge of the maps and mechanics--and did a little better. The ending of this little narrative is powerful.The only thing that knocks this down to 9/10 is that it crashed on Mac (a QA misstep acknowledged by the studio), forcing me to replay almost an entire level.Hats off to Johannes Wadin and Might & Delight. I confess I was a little disappointed to see they have made a sequel. A major appeal of this game is how one-of-a-kind it is. I'm not sure what a sequel can add.

Posted: March 23
												I don't usually get upset when people die, but when animals die......the world just endssssssss. RIP my 3 lost badger babies you will be dearly missed by your mother honey badger and your 2 brothers, manuka and clover. 10/10 will stab you right in the heart

Posted: January 21, 2016
												GIMME SHELTER-You are the mother of a group of badger pups. It's your job--nay, DUTY--to keep these babies alive. You have to feed them and protect them from the elements and an evil bird of prey.-The main game is very short, about an hour, and it features a linear narrative. The badger family goes through danger after danger. Not everyone necessarily makes it in one piece, either. Yes, the pups can die.-This is true survival horror.-The story lacks any words and uses cutscenes very minimalistically, yet it tells a very compelling story. Survival is a key theme here, but it goes beyond this in ways I probably shouldn't reveal. It speaks for itself. It's a simple, yet mentally satisfying story.-The music sets a peaceful ambience when it needs to, but also knows how to keep you on your toes for the more thrilling sections. Great soundtrack.-After you beat the game there is an optional mode called "Nurture." I did not play it myself, but evidently it's a more arcade version of the main game. Instead of following a story, you focus entirely on feeding the pups for an unknown number of days.FINAL VERDICT-I don't know if it's really worth the asking price, but I would certainly recommend it on sale. Just make sure you know what you're getting into before purchasing. The story is the meat of this game and it's only about an hour long. Sure, there is a bonus mode you could play for hours, but I don't think the gameplay itself warrants continued play. While the controls are fine--minimal, but satisfying enough--they aren't enough for me to want to play the non-story variant. I would love to play more if there was another story involved, but otherwise I can't see myself coming back to this one. If you want to explore a good example of minimalistic storytelling in video games, I would recommend Shelter.

												Lots of people will say this game was boring for them, and they wouldn't be wrong. If you flip through the discussion posts about this game though, everyone who does have something good to say usually starts with how awful it is when you lose your first baby badger. Brutal. I came here after reading about Shelter on a modern art blog (Hyperallergic), and I agree with them that the slow pacing, narrative weight and emotional investment that the game brings out in players are the greatest strengths of the game. The art style is incredibly relaxing as well... get it on sale if you're not sure about it, but my recommendation is here.

Posted: January 1, 2014
												The most distressing game I've played since Penumbra, Its like someone got around to making a video game based on watership down.  You have absolutely no stated goal, though in the first minute of the game its implied the purpose is to keep your cubs alive. Youll start by wandering around, picking up food for them (entirely because they eat it when you drop it - there is nothing telling you how hungry or full they are or need to be, and they never stop eating) then learn to hunt other animals juuuust before you are shown you can be hunted too. Youll need to apply what you learned from being the hunter to survive being the prey, the primary lesson being "Your cubs are loud and stupid, and youre just going to have to figure out how to work around that"Its one big stealth escort mission, but you wont mind it while you sit in silent horror as your cubs playfully trot out in the open while a hungry falcon flies overhead. It also doesnt help that the game is a looker, and the soundtrack calming.

Posted: January 10, 2014
												This little game packs a huge emotional punch. The aim is to keep your brood of cute little baby badgers alive - you get attached to them very quickly, so be prepared to feel like the worst person in the world if one dies. They're wayward little scamps who don't always go where you want them to, which keeps things interesting. The world is also very pretty to look at, which always helps. People you cohabit with will also get some amusement from your gameplay - mainly due to your irrational cries of 'GET AWAY FROM MY BABY' peppered with the odd 'JUST EAT THE STUPID TURNIP - NO, NOT YOU, I MEANT STRIPY - GAAAAAAH'

Posted: January 8, 2014
												Shelter was a game I had been reading about for a while and kind of forgot about. However, upon rediscovering it, buying it and playing it, I found that it offers a very unique experience not found anywhere else! You play as a mother badger trying to escort her young along the paths of growing up and maturing to the point of taking care of themselves. You will escort them away from hungry flying owls, wolves in the night, forest fires and even huge waves of water trying to sweep them away! I found myself caring too much for those little guys. And you'll also find that the ending is completely bitter sweet. Definitely worth your time.

Posted: January 10, 2014
												As another reviewer said, welcome to BADGER SIMULATOR 2013!I recommend ignoring the hype and deciding what you are looking for in a game before trying.Your enjoyment of Shelter will be largely influenced by what you look for in a game. If you go into Shelter looking for a fin traditional game then you may be disappointed. What Shelter offers in this department is non-traditional graphics, invisible walls, long corridors with little explorations, lite-survival and caretaking elements, some somewhat neat stealth take downs, and annoying birds of death. Oh, and bugs that will cause your badger children to die. However, if you are looking for a game that also offeres a unique and harrowing experience that puts you in the shoes of motherhood in the animal wilds, trying to do whatever it takes as an omnivore in the middle of the food chain. The graphics remind me of picture books from childhood, recalling tales and fables about animals and their children in their world, full of morals and whatnot. This may be bunk to others, but as an artist it drew me into the world and realitic//naturalistc grapics would have had a lesser effect on me.The soundtrack itself is wonderful, blending into the game perfectly. I cannot say much about it specificly other than it filled the world just right, layering and never pulling me away.The sound effects are good as they should be, the badgers yip and yap in communication, the predatory birds caws are terrifying when first heard, and other animals sounds serve as environmental clues. This is all as it should be.So the real meat of this gaming experience comes to down to the scripted experiences you progress through. Your badger children age and grow as you take them through several environments, each containing various hazards such as darkness, fire, and flooding. You must constantly provide them food of either the vegetable of flesh variety. If you are not the type of person looking to be placed in the role of protector, mother, leader, provider; if you don't find yourself becoming emotionally attached as you play games, then you may want to give Shelter a pass.I am a white male gamer, age 32 and fall somewhere in the middle of attachment/unattachment. When my first two badger died to something in the darkness I was sad, but I expected it sooner or later. They were weak and scared. When my next child died in a flood it was upsetting but I still had two strong children to look out for. When one of them was taken by a large raptor because I took a wrong turn in some underground tunnels and came out the dangerous end, I was screaming at the top of my lungs at the computer screen.This game go to me.

Posted: January 26, 2014
												Any game that can make you feel is a good game. I was immediately drawn in by the concept, the graphics, and the execution. Evading the eagle was harrowing and I subconciously ended up naming my puppies. Then, during the night level, I lost one of my puppies...and I was hooked. I felt sad. I felt loss. I felt remorse. I felt an overpowering desire to do better and pay more attention to my puppies. AAA titles could learn a lot from Shelter; it is a great game.

Posted: January 26, 2014
												I jumped right on this when I saw it had "badger simulator" written all over it, and found it to be... disappointing. For $10 AUD, I'd expect more than a little under an hours worth of actual play time. The concept is great, however the actual execution was lacking. Also dat gamma setting. Everything is incredibly washed out in white, and I ended up losing two pups to starvation because the slight shade difference in a "healthy" pup and a "hungry" pup is almost completely unnoticeable.While a lack of tutorial might be desireable to some, it's needed when a large portion of players do not understand why they cannot leave the barrow. And of course, there are also a few bugs that need to be ironed out.If you'd like to give it a try, definitely wait until it's on sale. As it currently stands, it is not worth the retail price.

Posted: January 26, 2014
												If you liked the unique aesthetics and interactive-soundscapey-ness of Proteus, Shelter might be the game for you. It also sports a clearer objective - you're a mother badger, you've got five baby badgers to feed and take care of, and the rest of the world is against you (or at least, the rest of the world that's bigger than you are). Along the way you'll be contending with hungry birds, sneaky foxes, surging rapids and raging fires, all whilst you try to keep your quintet of kids in check. It's a short experience - little more than an hour - but a memorable one, and the soundtrack is utterly superb. Stay past the end credits for a scene that ties a nice, thoughtful bow around the whole package.

Posted: December 25, 2013
												In this game, you play as a badger. Yes, a badger. And it is awesome. The graphics are stylized and strikingly beautiful, and the music is excellent, always fitting the mood and indicating different things going on (if a baby has just eaten, if a predator is nearby, and so on). You must care for your five little baby badgers, and if you don't, you WILL feel like a heartless monster. My only qualm with this game is that the camera will sometimes go through trees (though this never happened at any crucial moments), but otherwise this is an excellent short game.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												This game is simply beautiful. A true work of art. Sound was great and the art style was appropriate and stunning. The main objective in this game is to survive as the mother badger and to help the baby badgers get food and to protect them from predators. As the badger troop trudges on, they encounter many obstacles, such as hawks, coursing rivers, and raging fires. Along the way, the mother can kill smaller game and pick fruits growing on trees or in the ground to give to the children. As the children eat more, they grow more, and become less of a liability.I've never become as attached to a main character as I was to this mother. Maybe that's just because these cute little animals are adorable (when the mother isn't leaping 20 feet and killing mice). Regardless, I enjoyed my journey with this family, and even gave the young ones names (Sam and Daisy were my favorite, don't tell the others.)It's a short game, but I think the overall experience and possible ability to start new journeys once the ending has been reached make up for that. I'd buy it again in a heartbeat.

Posted: June 20, 2015
												This game is very emotionally intense. The baby badgers suck you in with their cute little barks and whimpers. And protecting them from a giant death bird bonds you for life. And then you notice that you only have four trailing behind you. So you go look for the lost baby badger, and you see him gray and lifeless a ways back. Or you'll see your pups run off only to have there be one less when they get back. And that's really hard. I'm sure there are some folks who can handle that; personally I cried like a dingo ate my baby when the last one got swept away in a flood. From an artistic standpoint, this game is flawless. It hooks the player in and gets them emotionally attached to its nameless little characters, each one with its own individual patterning. And it'll rip your heart out. Play with caution.

Posted: February 3, 2015
												Shelter is a beautiful game; the art style is pared down while still being both pleasing and engaging. The music is similarly haunting, with sparse percussion accented by big open chords. You play as a mother badger, looking after your five cubs. You must find them food, guide them through fire and flood, protect them from predators that strike without warning.The game is short -- about two hours -- but in that time it mangaged to evoke emotion without a single word of text or spoken dialog; it was a great example of "show don't tell", the best kind of interactive storytelling. The end, in particular, is quite poetic. And if the phrase "interactive storytelling" didn't just make you stop reading in disgust, Shelter is certainly worth your time.

												Definitely worth it for the 2 dollars I paid.I did emotionally become attached to my baby badgers as the game progressed, however there were some gameplay issues that detracted from the experience.I dislike it when levels force me to walk, rather than run. It just takes me out of the experience. Only one level did this though. The dangers of the environment are harsh, but realistically so. Nature is crazy after all.The only other thing was, there's no explanation as to how to do anything, but it's simple enough to figure out as you go. I guess that's a metaphor for life? Either way, it's a good game. I enjoyed it.Only 1/5 of my baby badgers survived. I am a terrible Badger mom.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Sit down child (or, rather, stay in your seat I guess), and I will tell you how a game named Shelter not only will destroy your emotional center for the day, but also how it strangely makes you happy that you are not a badger mommy.Artistic beauty aside, Shelter is a story about you, a badger mom who just had five badger babies and need to keep them alive. You need to avoid starvation (as a baby badger that's hungry turns grey as it withers and dies), drowning (in a river with surfer waves that snatch your children away), fires of death (that chase you and eats your babies if you don't run fast enough) and 'murica (haha, no, but seriously, even eagles want to eat your babies, what is that about, badgers eat you eagle dugnubbit).I'd be lying if I said I didn't care whether or not my badger babies made it out okay, and that they're just a life-bar for me to get through the game and see some pretty neat sights. I suddenly realized what true motherly pain feels like over losing ones brood (or its fake, videogame-induced cousin, I guess), and genuinely panicked whenever that blasted eagle swooped down to snatch little Michael Jackson (Yes, I named my badger babies). I've said this about a lot of games lately, but the way it envelops me is just amazing, and the way the story (though little there is) just wraps around to thank all mothers leaves you satisfied rather than upset (you'll se what I mean if you play through it).The game is short, but there's a lot to what it has. Personally, I don't think much of the after-game mode where you can care for badger babies and have them grow up, but they'll die if you don't feed them daily or something. The story-mode, however, is what makes it work, and if a game can make much of very little, that's immensely okay to me.

Posted: July 20, 2015
												Note: You definitely need/want an external mouse hooked up to play this game if you're using a laptop keyboard. You control movement with the WASD keys, and look around with mouse. This game is exactly what the gameplay video shows: no plot beyond getting from point a to point b, no surprise twists, and no level ups. It takes about an hour to play through. If these things are not your cup of tea, do not buy this game. If it is, and the game play video appeals: that is the game you are going to get. Enjoy! I resigned myself to only saving 1 of the cubs after I noticed that the hungrier siblings could be shoved out of the way by the others, and end up dieing of starvation unless I micromanaged the eating order. I am happy with my decision - it's like I'm taking revenge on every stupid AI I've had to escort in past video game ever. The art style is something different, and the soundtrack is very important to set the emotional tone in the game - there was clear effort made there.

												Oh, where to begin with this game.They're asking 10 dollars for a game that has about an hour of adventure for you. Posted: June 20, 2015
												This game is very emotionally intense. The baby badgers suck you in with their cute little barks and whimpers. And protecting them from a giant death bird bonds you for life. And then you notice that you only have four trailing behind you. So you go look for the lost baby badger, and you see him gray and lifeless a ways back. Or you'll see your pups run off only to have there be one less when they get back. And that's really hard. I'm sure there are some folks who can handle that; personally I cried like a dingo ate my baby when the last one got swept away in a flood. From an artistic standpoint, this game is flawless. It hooks the player in and gets them emotionally attached to its nameless little characters, each one with its own individual patterning. And it'll rip your heart out. Play with caution.

												This game is inscrutable. I picked up a pineapple, dropped it, it rolled down a hill past an invisible wall, and I walked around trying to interact with things for a while. Eventually, I alt+F4'd out, started over, and walked about some woods for a bit before running out of fruit to give to my little badgers. Posted: August 28, 2013
												Just finished this in an hour and I liked it.  What you get: A mostly mellow journey through what is basically a 3D painting, leading your five cubs through various dangers and foraging for food along the way. Why I liked it: The art style was refreshing and unique, and I had fun trying to keep my litter alive. The ending came abruptly but was fitting and makes me want to try again to see if I can save more than two of my cubs. Don't expect action or a deep sim-type experience from this. If you can appreciate a unique visual aesthetic, a nice soundtrack, and how everything blends to create an immersive world you may think ten dollars was worth it. I did.

Posted: August 9, 2014
												"Shelter" is an unfortunate mix of very good and very frustrating.The sound direction is excellent, as is the music, which is rustic and ambient, with an undertone of danger that fits the game perfectly.The art is purposefully abstract - the world looks like an elaborate quilt. Unfortunately the beauty is weirdly washed-out, and since there are no options for adjusting the graphics, there's nothing you can do short of cranking down the brightness of your monitor. The camera is problematic, frequently getting stuck behind or inside geometry in the ubiquitous tight spaces and dense foliage.The gameplay is sometimes tense, sometimes frustrating, but most often tedious.The frustrating parts are largely due to the rules of the game being unclear. Can I actually feed individual cubs, or not? (I found later on that I could, although they would frequently just get stuck spinning around the food, without being able to eat it.) Did I have to sneak through tall grass to avoid birds of prey? (No.) Could I avoid them by hiding under bushes? (No.) Can the river drown my cubs? (No. I mean yes. Sometimes, but not always. What the hell?)The nighttime sequence was especially annoying. The game forces you to move slowly, makes everything beyond a foot or so impossible to see, and has your cubs run away from you at random intervals. Fail to chase them down, and they're simply lost forever.The best parts of the game are the tense parts - when you're being hunted by birds of prey, and when you're fleeing through the forest fire. These sequences are exciting, and even offer a break from the otherwise linear track as you decide which grassy patch you'll flee to next.The remainder of the game is largely monotonous. You wander through a series of foresty corridors, digging up roots and tossing them to the kids. Occasionally you catch a small, furry thing. And toss it to the kids.I like the idea of the game, but it's fairly flawed, despite its relatively short play-time. If the concept sounds interesting to you, wait for it to go on sale.

Posted: April 1, 2014
												The moment you are constantly turning your camera around to check on your pups: you'll know Shelter has reached its goal. Shelter is a thrilling, upsetting, and sadly short, journey about a mother badger taking care of her young. The game clearly puts a lot of thought into the life of being a parent, and it really pulls it off for the player. During my first playthrough of Shelter i lost one pup; although close to the end of the level, i ran back trying to find him/her and i felt awful. I could not find him/her or simply load a save: I had lost one of my children. Shelter immerses the player into the role of a parent amazingly well and it only drives you in deeper as you constantly feed and nurture your children in order for them to stay alive. I am surprised this title has not won an indie game award for its immersive atmosphere and beautiful environment; but nevertheless, it is still a treat: award or no award. If you're looking for an immersive atmosphere and a huge focus on captivating the player, then buy Shelter.

Posted: April 1, 2014
												A simple game baced around protecting 5 baby badgers that you lead around the forest and away from harm. For 5 AI that could potential screw up a game, they  follow your every comand, I've never encounterd a problem with them, litteraly flawless. They even sit down and wait there turn to be fed, if you give them 2 or 3 seconds go get oriented. All of the levels vary heavily so its never like your looking or playing the same thing, each level has a different challenge as well. The art style works in the games favor as well, even a net book could run it and looks great. The controls are easy to get used to and never put you at an unfair disadvantage. Easily the best part of the game is you feel bad when you let one of your cubs get out of sight or die. I felt my heart drop every time an of them died or even got out of my sight, there is a real drive to see them all live throughout the adventure. At the time of this review the game is only $2.50 and honestly its more than worth it. the adventures thrilling, the asthetics are nice and at the end you feel happy yet sad. Give shelter a try.

Posted: May 19, 2014
												Shelter is a beautiful game depicting the life of a mother badger. I love the art style, but the text is often unreadable (fortunately only menu text is important). It only has partial controller support (you need a mouse to use the menus and the control tips are for keyboard and mouse). It's a short and interesting story told entirely through actions.Technically it's entirely an escort mission with stealth elements, but Might & Delight manage to use the escort format to connect you to your pups and make you regret their demise.I completed the main story and took a stab at the "nurture" mode (under extras) and wasn't interested enough to grab more than one turnip. I didn't see enough there to make fetch quests fun, but I didn't really give it a chance. Maybe later.

Posted: March 12
												So... how to describe Shelter? Saying it is unique seems too superficial, and it doesn't do the game credit to be honest. In this modern day and age where the market has been oversaturated with many games that can easily be classified as "mindless run, gun & slash" fastfood entertainment, some developers try something different. Imagine a hybrid of a Bambi/Lion King animal based story, with a clear Circle of Life theme, spiced with loss, altruism and tragedy and an artistic painted storybook look to it. Art and emotion. That's Shelter. The game, in all it's simplicity and with its limited length and replay value grabs a hold of you and leaves you in equal measure impressed, feeling uneasy and with renewed insight of how fragile life can be, especially in the Wilds as part of the food chain. As you see, Shelter can't be defined or categorised easily and both topic, style and gameplay might not be for everyone... BUT what it does, it does very well and I can recommend this small but shiny gem to anyone who's up for experiencing "something different".In short:Pros:- Artistic- Unique- Experience a painfully clear Circle of Life story- Appeals to your emotions and has a psychological impact- Clings to your thoughts long after you stopped playingCons:- Graphic style won't appeal to everyone- Short- Simple- Low replay value- Controls can be a bit cumbersome

Posted: August 27, 2014
												ART&MUSIC: The artistic quality of the game was one of my favorite aspects. The color remained vivd throughout, creating a different atmosphere than most. The rain had to be one of my favorites as red was everywhere (not the typical blue), and the music that matched -- abosultely stunning. CHARACTERS: Well, they are badgers. There's not much to them, but you certainly get attached. GAMEPLAY: I never ran into any problems...well, I did get lost a few times. However, that really made the game for me. Panicking, wondering where the 'mother' is supposed to go to next to get away from danger just added to the quality of the game. 8/10: It's short. I want to play through again and take the time to really make the badgers grow, but again it's REALLY short. What broke the game for me was the end result. Given that the game has such a 'dropoff' ending I would still recommend it for the music, art, and concept that it has to offer. Definitely can't wait for the second!

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Even though I feel like this game missed out on realizing its full thematic potential, I still found it more emotionally stirring and visually mesmerizing than many much bigger titles out there. Shelter toys with players' familiarity with game conventions and our notions of a control-success correlation by allowing randomness to factor into the cubs' survival. Although I think the developers did this to emphasize themes of survival-of-the-fittest and the inevitable losses of parenthood, it doesn't make for the most enjoyable gameplay experience. At just over an hour, Shelter is just the right length as it compresses and contextualizes these themes admirably, yet still fails to provide a compelling progression of gameplay mechanics. While I would have liked to have seen the game more fully fleshed-out, I still laud Might and Delight for tackling such unconventional subject matter within the medium.

Then there is the always haunting threat of starvation.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												I....don't know how I feel about this "game". "Piece of art" is more fitting. I "beat" it in about an hour (not rushing through, though you can probably take up to 1.5 hours) and I am certainly left with a set of feels I didn't expect going into the experience. Not worth the full price, but for the $2.50 I spent (far less than than half of a movie ticket that would give me only slightly more than double the entertainment length) it was well worth it. Be aware, there is little to no replayability, but the conversations you can have about the game could go well on into the night.

Posted: April 8, 2015
												When I first got this game, I had trouble running the thing! The graphics weren't loading on the title page, and once the game "Started" I could hear background noises and the sounds of animal cries. Yet I couldn't see a thing! Just a white screen saying "Loading".I posted on the forums, and got no response. I tried contacting the developers...again, no response. I eventually managed to get the game going, by heading to the games steam folder, and setting it's compatibility mode for Windows 98/me (for some reason). Then the game would run, but hang when you exited it..I fixed this by running shelter as admin.Finally it all worked! So if you have similar problems, try that! Now, about the game!This game is heavily stylized and while beautiful, can be hard to make things out since items and creatures are of abnormal shapes. Even when you can make out the item, it still might be difficult to find things(Say, a hopping frog) due to the fact that the colors used in the game are all so light, that it makes everything seem faded and washed out.Other than that, playing as a mommy Honey Badgers leading her children through the treacherous wilds is incredibly enjoyable. The trouble getting the game running, was well worth the effort, and while the game is fantastic, it has HORRIBLE support.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												This game is oddly compelling. I just finished my first playthrough today, and I'm already looking forward to playing it again. The controls are extremely simplistic - you use the WASD keys to move, the SHIFT key to move faster, and the left mouse button to pull up food like turnips and radishes, pounce on prey, and give food to one of your five growing badger children. You get surprisingly attached to said badger children as the game progresses,  and losing one of them is a horrifying and severely depressing experience. Successfully completing a level with all remaining babies still intact is unexpectedly rewaring. If you're looking for a short, (mostly) calm, emotionally investing and altogether beautiful experience, Shelter is definitely the game for you.

												Definitely an “artsy” game. If you aren’t the type of person who sees games as another form of artistic expression, don’t bother with this. The graphics are a stylized, washed-out look and the gameplay is minimalistic, to put it generously. It seems extremely insubstantial for MSRP, and if I had paid that I’d feel cheated. However, 50% or more off and I’d be happy with the purchase.Just a note: developer, why did you pick the most evil animal on Earth for us to be sympathetic for? Maybe that was the cunning plan: to show those terrifying creatures from Farcry 4 to just be trying to survive…by biting people’s legs off.

Posted: August 31, 2013
												You're looking at a game that has zero replayability, melodramatic, and unfulfilling.  The ending could have been different and would have been much more emotional as what they were obviously trying to go for.*****SPOILERS*****Yes, the mom dies and whatever badgers you have remaining are left to fend for themselves without you knowing what happens to them.  If the ending was reversed (meaning the cubs die while the mom is left all alone) then it would have been a much better and emotional ending since they were going for the whole "damn nature, you scary"*****END SPOILERS*****The game was as long as it needed to be which was a good thing.  It got it's point it was trying to give across.  It's a basic game that does leave a lot to be desired though.  It's not so much about surviving nature, but more about running from a ♥♥♥♥ing stalker bird the entire time which I feel was the developer's only idea of challenge so they took that and ran 5 miles with it.  In all honesty though, I don't think there would have been much more to do with the game as far as variety.  It's a very hard idea to work with and I feel they did a good enough job with it where by the end, I respected what they did and how they managed to do it.  Would I ever play the game again?  No.  Would I recommend it to anyone else?  Unless you are VERY curious about it, no.  With it priced at 10 dollars, it's not worth the price.  I feel probably 5 dollars would have been more appropriate.

I think this comes in just behind Dear Esther, and thats one of my favourite games of this genre.After a while you do get attached to these little badger pups and when I lost my first one to that stupid eagle... lets just say now I hate eagles. It is so hard to keep everyone alive and thats what happens in reality and I think this game has captured that perfectly. Although also like most games of this genre I dont think there is much replay value there, and I did get bored after a while, I still think Shelter ranks up there with other tear jerker indie titles.10/10 from me

Posted: March 13
												While this game is very fun to play, occassionally scary and heart breaking, I keep running into a problem that involves food the mother picks up and never drops.  This usually happens when one of the babies is too hungry to move on, and I cannot go back to feed it as it would have been eaten by wolves or a hawk or something else entirely.  The food stays in the mouth, and I cannot get other food for the remaining babies.  However, no matter how many times I try, I also cannot drop the said food for any of the remaining babies alive.I came here to see when the game was first released, thinking maybe that this is a small glitch and that it was being worked on in the process, only to find out that this game has been out since 2013, and I'm going to guess that no one has found this bug, or it has been found and reported with no patch to fix it.I still want to play the game and enjoy myself, though I hate having to reset the level that I am on at least 10 times just to not run into this small complication.

Posted: December 14, 2014
												If I could describe this game in two words, it would be beautiful, and sad. The game basically revolves around you, the Badger mother, trying to keep your kin alive. You harvest food, sneak around (There are birds that hunt you, and yes, they are frieghtening), and explore. The game sets a tone of bright and innocent in earlier levels, and becomes dark and depressing in later stages. I personally fell in love with the kin and really, REALLY, wanted them all to survive. But, this objective was diminished in one level where it seemed impossible to get through without one of the small badgers dying (leaving only a peep noise). This made me very angry as it seemed like a design choice, ruining my experiance. But maybe this is the devs teaching us something....You can't always have what you want, your heart WILL be broken and sometimes there is nothing you can do about it. Maybe im thinking about it too much. I did cry (like a little ♥♥♥♥♥) when I first finished the game and was a little disappointed about the ending (see previous points). But overall this game was a great experiance and I highly recommend it to everyone!!! 8.5/10

												Shelter คือเกมส์ Indie เกมส์นึงที่จะนำคุณไปสู่ชีวิตเจ้า Badger 6 ตัว แม่/พ่อ 1 ลูก 5 กับการผจญภัยที่ประสบภัยต่างๆ-Graphicทำออกมาได้ตาม Style เกมส์ Indie ดีอาจจะทำให้ปวดตาบางช่วงเพราะเรื่องสีเกมส์นี้กลมกลืนกันมาก-Gameplayสำหรับใครที่ขวัญอ่อน(แบบผม)ขี้กลัวจะสะดุ้งบ่อยหน่อยในเกมส์มีสัตว์ 3 ชนิด กบ จิ้งจอก เหยี่ยว(อันนี้ตกใจสุด) Controls น้อยเล่นได้ง่ายๆ-Storyสำหรับผมแล้วออกแนว Drama เพราะเห็นลูกตายทีไรผมรู้สึกว่าเป็นความผิดผมแล้วเห็นใจ พ่อ/แม่ว่ากว่าจะเลี้ยงมาได้ TT ในเกมส์แล้วจะมีทั้ง 5 ChaptersChapter 1 จะไม่มีไรมากเดินตามทางไปเรื่อยๆและหลบหนีเหยี่ยวในท้าย ChapterChapter 2 เป็นตอนกลางคืนก็ไม่ต่างไรมากเดินตามทางเดินไปเรื่อยChapter 3 เป็นพายุเข้าโดยจะให้เราเดินข้ามแม่นํ้าเยอะหน่อยChapter 4 เป็นตอนที่ป่าไหม้เราจะต้องเดินผ่านป่าที่ไหม้นั้นไปอีกฝั่งที่ปลอดภัยChapter 5 เป็นฉากสุดท้ายของเกมส์นี้โดยจะเดินไปเรื่อยๆแต่จะเจออุปสรรค์ 2 อย่าง จิ้งจอก กับ เหยี่ยวสำหรับใครที่ไม่รู้วิธีผ่านไปได้ที่ Guide ใน Steam น่ะครับเป็นภาษาอังกฤษไปแปลกันเอาเองขอขอบคุณที่มาอ่าน Review กันน่ะครับผิดพลาดตรงไหนบอกได้ครับ

Posted: January 14, 2015
												Shelter is an adventure survival game centered around playing as a mother badger, giving an overall pleasurable experience. Chances are that if you came to this page to view the game that means that you are okay with playing artistic indie games, and at a price of $10 I think this game is well worth the experience it supplies (and for those of you who are on a budget, this game can be picked up for around $2-3 during Steam sales whether it be Fall, Winter, or Summer). As a survival adventure game, Shelter exceeds in its art style, which in my opinion can be best described as Low-Poly (if you play the game and grow to love the art style there is a couple of wonderful subreddits that showcase this kind of art style called /r/lowpoly, /r/low_poly, and /r/lowpoly2d). Overall the experience is superb as you play as a mother badger who is sheltering her five cubs, with an overall arching story that is very compelling and what I would describe as short and sweet. I believe in moderation of story time, and Shelter can take roughly 60-90 minutes to complete. This may sound short to you, but there is an option for multiple play throughs as one may wish to complete the game with all five cubs (if they did not achieve that the first time) althought the ending will always be the same. An additional mode was added at some point called "Nurture" (under "extras" on the menu) which essentially allow you to play the game in a reminescent Tamagotchi like way. I mean this in  the sense that you are now allowed to explore the open world as a badger and *constantly revisit* your five cubs *every day* to *nurture* and feed them until they are adults. It's a relaxing game mode to me since it's a good way to unwind and passively listen to Shelter's amazing sound score. Things that I did not like about the game mostly revolve around how the cubs that you are to protect have a janky AI which can be unresponsive in following you sometimes (it can range from not many occurences on a level to a fair amount) leading to the AI's impending death and you as the player completing the game without all five cubs. Another thing I noticed was that the environment may appear to be open world, but at least in the campaign mode you are very limited in what and where you can explore. Now in the "extra" feature mode of Nurture this is slightly alleviated but is still present. These two complaints of mine DO NOT DETRACT FROM THE OVERALL EXPERIENCE of the game, but are things that I reflected upon and complained about upon completion of the game. I would HIGHLY recommend this game, and it's coming sequel called Shelter 2 released by the same studio Might and Delight where in Shelter 2 you play as a lynx and have a supposedly more control and freedom over the open world. The trailer is absolutely magnificent and Shelter 2 will be released sometime next month. If it is anything like Shelte was then it will be a superb game with unique and touching plot points.
