Posted: June 23, 2014
												It's a badger sim, so that should tell you whether you should buy it or not.You play a mother badger who, with slim pickings in her territory, decides to move her five cubs to a more prosperous area. On the way you must keep the babies fed and safe from predators and natural disaster.I've heard a lot of praise for the graphics. They weren't my cup of tea, to be honest. They reminded me a lot of the wire-model Tekken 2 characters and sometimes it was hard to see where to go because of them. Also there were a tonne of times where I couldn't see what was happening because the camera swung into the middle of a tree. Most of the time this wasn't a big deal but during the night-time sequence where it is essential to be able to see where you're going, it was almost a game-breaker for me. The game's ability to play on your emotions is definitely its strong point. I was genuinely distressed when I lost the babies to any of the various calamities and accidentally setting my entire badger family on fire made me feel truly terrible inside. But the fact that I could feel so strongly after a short play-time says a lot.The price point is a bit high for what this game is, but if it seems like something you're interested in then it's worth a look during the sales.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Two notes! It's pretty bright - part of the chosen style. Because of that, make sure to play it either during the day or in a well-lit room, unless you're a fan of eye strain. The other bit, it's a pretty short experience.Those two things said, it's still a really cute, artful thing! If you like either of those descriptors, you should maybe give it a shot!Also, if you're patient enough for it, there's an additional 'Nurture' mode, where you're supposed to play the game once a real-world day (as the time in this mode is tied to your computer's clock), bringing food to the baby cubs. By around day 5 or so they'll be big enough to walk around, and the longer you keep up that routine, the more open the game world becomes.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Shelter is something unique.As someone who spent their young life dreaming of games where you could be an animal and experience life as one, Shelter is something I had to have.You play as an adult badger tending to their young. You start with 5 cubs and your goal is to migrate through the world you live in to reach a new area for your cubs. Along the way you'll encounter different environments, hazards, and obstacles that you need to overcome whilst still making sure that none of your cubs starve or die. Which is harder than it sounds.The experience is serene, and does portray nature as it is - sometimes cruel despite it's beauty. Danger can lurk everywhere, and hearts will break when cubs are lost along the way due to unexpected circumstances or a simple lapse of attention. If you're looking for something action-packed, this is not for you. It's slow-paced and it's emphasis is on the circle of life and taking things as they come, day after day.The game may not be entirely glitch free (one of my cubs fell off a cliff), but it's definitely worth playing if you're looking for something different. The only thing you should note if you're thinking of buying this is that it's short. The entire game can be played through in roughly about an hour.Would still recommend this for everyone who's ever wanted to become an animal for a short period of time - because that's what Shelter is at its core. It was a lovely experience for me, and with Shelter 2 now on the way, I'll be eagerly waiting for it!

Posted: August 28, 2013
												Just finished this in an hour and I liked it.  What you get: A mostly mellow journey through what is basically a 3D painting, leading your five cubs through various dangers and foraging for food along the way. Why I liked it: The art style was refreshing and unique, and I had fun trying to keep my litter alive. The ending came abruptly but was fitting and makes me want to try again to see if I can save more than two of my cubs. Don't expect action or a deep sim-type experience from this. If you can appreciate a unique visual aesthetic, a nice soundtrack, and how everything blends to create an immersive world you may think ten dollars was worth it. I did.

Posted: August 9, 2014
												"Shelter" is an unfortunate mix of very good and very frustrating.The sound direction is excellent, as is the music, which is rustic and ambient, with an undertone of danger that fits the game perfectly.The art is purposefully abstract - the world looks like an elaborate quilt. Unfortunately the beauty is weirdly washed-out, and since there are no options for adjusting the graphics, there's nothing you can do short of cranking down the brightness of your monitor. The camera is problematic, frequently getting stuck behind or inside geometry in the ubiquitous tight spaces and dense foliage.The gameplay is sometimes tense, sometimes frustrating, but most often tedious.The frustrating parts are largely due to the rules of the game being unclear. Can I actually feed individual cubs, or not? (I found later on that I could, although they would frequently just get stuck spinning around the food, without being able to eat it.) Did I have to sneak through tall grass to avoid birds of prey? (No.) Could I avoid them by hiding under bushes? (No.) Can the river drown my cubs? (No. I mean yes. Sometimes, but not always. What the hell?)The nighttime sequence was especially annoying. The game forces you to move slowly, makes everything beyond a foot or so impossible to see, and has your cubs run away from you at random intervals. Fail to chase them down, and they're simply lost forever.The best parts of the game are the tense parts - when you're being hunted by birds of prey, and when you're fleeing through the forest fire. These sequences are exciting, and even offer a break from the otherwise linear track as you decide which grassy patch you'll flee to next.The remainder of the game is largely monotonous. You wander through a series of foresty corridors, digging up roots and tossing them to the kids. Occasionally you catch a small, furry thing. And toss it to the kids.I like the idea of the game, but it's fairly flawed, despite its relatively short play-time. If the concept sounds interesting to you, wait for it to go on sale.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												A short yet beautiful adventure where your maternal/paternal instincts take over. It's a charming and short game about motherhood and trying to protect your young in a cold world. The game clocks in a little over an hour yet it doesn't overstay its welcome with its simplistic mechanics of feeding your young, trying to keep them together and keeping them from being devoured. The game is pretty simple but keeping your young alive is surprisingly difficult and over the course of your hour you'll find plenty of twists and turns and new mechanics to keep things free. You'll mostly be wandering around, trying to feed your children by either knocking down apples or even hunting small animals. There will even be times where you are met with more children than food and you have to choose who to feed (hungry children will fade and grow weaker and slower making them easy prey). Avoiding eagles, creatures of the night, trying to keep them calm when they run away scared and keeping them alive during natural disasters makes you grow attached to them. My only criticism is that for a game so short there are loading screens (which are quick) but load into very different areas of the forest. Such a short game would have been much better at providing a more seamless transition between the "areas" of the forest. All in all it's a great game.

Posted: March 12
												So... how to describe Shelter? Saying it is unique seems too superficial, and it doesn't do the game credit to be honest. In this modern day and age where the market has been oversaturated with many games that can easily be classified as "mindless run, gun & slash" fastfood entertainment, some developers try something different. Imagine a hybrid of a Bambi/Lion King animal based story, with a clear Circle of Life theme, spiced with loss, altruism and tragedy and an artistic painted storybook look to it. Art and emotion. That's Shelter. The game, in all it's simplicity and with its limited length and replay value grabs a hold of you and leaves you in equal measure impressed, feeling uneasy and with renewed insight of how fragile life can be, especially in the Wilds as part of the food chain. As you see, Shelter can't be defined or categorised easily and both topic, style and gameplay might not be for everyone... BUT what it does, it does very well and I can recommend this small but shiny gem to anyone who's up for experiencing "something different".In short:Pros:- Artistic- Unique- Experience a painfully clear Circle of Life story- Appeals to your emotions and has a psychological impact- Clings to your thoughts long after you stopped playingCons:- Graphic style won't appeal to everyone- Short- Simple- Low replay value- Controls can be a bit cumbersome

Posted: August 30, 2016



YouTube™ Video: Steam Cleaning - Shelter 

			Views: 6		

			Life as a badger is never easy, especially as a single parent raising their five kids while trying to take a road trip through eagle country.		

Life as a badger is never easy, especially as a single parent raising their five kids while trying to take a road trip through eagle country.A delightful world with a painterly visual style hides the sinister tones of harsh survival.  Five hungry mouths to feed plus multiple predators searching for their own meals.  Compounded by natural obstacles only further raises the stakes.The gameplay and mechanics are simple but most badgers are not required to hack consoles or solve international crises.  The minimalistic UI works well in the vast majority of the time, but some more visual clues for what to go would help the overall experience.

Posted: October 30, 2016
												First off let me start by saying im a severe ♥♥♥♥ing autist so feelings have always been a problem to feel or experience for me, with that in mind.Shelter is a very well thought out and done game where you are the mother of a family of badgers.You start the level off with one sick badger which already kicks your instincts in to care for it and to find it food so it can get better. This keypoint is very well managed throughout the game as you have a start of 5 badgers.In my playthrough i had 2 badgers left. 2 died of starvation because the others picked all the food and one died in the river.The one that died in the river, it's scream almost made me cry as i saw it flush down the river. I was like ohgod no.You care for the badgers intensely which is very well done imo, from scaring off enemies to finding food or making them feel safe.The visuals are a real eye pleaser and the lightning, scenery, music etc are very well fitting to the whole overall concept.I'd give it an 8/10, not a full 10 because personally i'd rather have seen an alternative ending to the current one where you perhaps grow old and your badgers visit or along that line. and the other point because muh badgers died :'<.Overall a very solid buy and worth the price but preferably on sale if you can get it.-Poise

You and your clan (yes, that's what a group of badgers is called according to Google.) will go through many different areas to reach the final area of the game. In each area, your badgers will grow a bit larger till they're as big as you are. This game can be easily completed in under 2 hours (I completed it in 1.7 hours), so it can be a game for just an affternoon of your time, or you can play it multiple times, like I probably will. Posted: June 2, 2014
												When I first found this game, i thought it was going to be a new and intriguing animal survival/simulator, a genre rarely touched or done well before. But it turned out that was only half the case. You only care for the badger kits, and you yourself do not need to eat at all (playing as the mother badger). The graphics are apealing and soundtrack is pleasant, but that means nothing to me if the gameplay isn't at its full potential, and im sure that a portion of the playerbase may feel the same. Plus it's very linear, not really having enough space to explore and have a grand adventure being lost in the woods. Don't get me wrong though, I did enjoy this game for the past hour and a half of playing it(which is the length of the game), foraging and occasionally hunting foxes, voles, and frogs to sate my babies' hunger. But i honestly think this game could have given a bit more in what it's focused on. Then again, I'm not entirely sure of the devolpers intentional feel they want the game to give to its players. If you want a charming, relaxing game that brings you closer to your [badger] family, then this may be one of those games. However, if you desire a more challenging game that truly tests your will to survive (this may be the case in the game's sequel: "Shelter 2"), than I'd suggest looking somewhere else.

Posted: March 12
												*****This review may be subjective... In reality the game... objectively speaking... is kind of a mediocre one... 63/100**** *And now considering what i felt... the feels I got and the joy I had...: Good game. At its standards and style... let's say 76/100... The story is beautiful... little bit sad (that's a reason why it is beautiful) but the nature is as it is. Art style is very good. Soundtrack if good enough. Gameplay isn't amazing (simplistic: collect food and avoid death) but I can say that at the first run it is quite challenging. Still... if you want to get to the end with all 5 babies... it is more than hard... I am seriously... you have to be very careful... The game may seem short... and it is... but longer with this content it will get boring... I hightly reccomand playing it looking at details and connecting to the world... if you rush in the game you will have a short run... i had a very nice and almost slow run and steam registered me 2.4 hours in the game. The game is nothing but a nice experience that I personally enjoyed and I think lots of you will enjoy it as well. ^*^*^IMPORTANT: The real problem here is that it may seem expensive... and unfortunately it is.  ~ 2 h gameplay and kind of a mediocre to be objective... it is not worth more than 6 euros... Consider at my review itself the fact that i bought this game at a sale.... and I paid 1,09 euros... If you're wondering to buy or not to buy this game... and you can relate a little bit to what i've said... than wait for a sale so the game is 6 euros or lower... otherwise... being one at my kind with tastes and things... you will get to the conclusion... good game... but i want my money back god damn it... you will realize is not worth 10 euros (as i said... 6 euros is pretty legit to me).Hope I helped at least a little bit.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												It's a cute and artistic game that will rip your heart out. I recommend this game being purchased on sale as I did because it's not very long and the replay value is pretty low. That being said I will say it is worth buying because you will be a stressed out mother badger about an hour in. It's a two-three hour long game but within that time you will get attached to those five baby badgers. You find yourself taking your time to feed them and think some of your decisions through. It makes it challenging in a way, considering i've attempted played through it three times and lost at least one baby each time. The game does a good job at making you play the part and get you emotionally invested. The controlls are very easy and the style of the game sometimes makes you want to stay in one place and look around, which isn't a good idea at times.  They also have a tomogatchi style pet side game when you beat the main game. You launch the game once a day for a month and watch your badgers go from completly dependant to fully grown. If you don't have the time for that then no big deal, the main game is enough.My only complaint is I wish they would have included some sort of extra content besides nurture, the side game. Maybe some developer content or even a third game mode.

												This is absolutely a lovely little game. You play as a badger and you're sole purpose is to make sure your five cubs stay alive. YouTube™ Video: Steam Cleaning - Shelter 

			Views: 6		

			Life as a badger is never easy, especially as a single parent raising their five kids while trying to take a road trip through eagle country.		

Life as a badger is never easy, especially as a single parent raising their five kids while trying to take a road trip through eagle country.A delightful world with a painterly visual style hides the sinister tones of harsh survival.  Five hungry mouths to feed plus multiple predators searching for their own meals.  Compounded by natural obstacles only further raises the stakes.The gameplay and mechanics are simple but most badgers are not required to hack consoles or solve international crises.  The minimalistic UI works well in the vast majority of the time, but some more visual clues for what to go would help the overall experience.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												Shelter came in a Humble Bundle for me eons ago. When I first got it, I fell in love with the graphics immediately. Shelter follows the story of Mother Badger and her five cubs. You have to overcome the challenges of the wild to ensure the survival of your litter. It's a quick game, with about an hour of game play, but a lasting impression. The game is moreso a moving art piece. The plot progresses slowly, changing only when the chapter shifts. Essentially, you set the pace for the game and you have limited freedom in exploration. Overall, the maps are pretty linear, but you can sniff around. The mechanics for the game are simple, and it's pretty low stress (apart from wanting to save your cubs). Feed them, feed yourself if you choose, and move forward. Pros:- Artistic masterpiece- Great sound track; super relaxing- I got pretty attached to all of the badgersCons: - Plot driven, but not a plot heavy game. Thats a pro or a con depending on what type of game you're looking for. - Pretty short game play. I wish it was just a little longer.- The flow between chapters appeared choppy at times. - I got pretty attached to all of the badgers :(

Posted: June 20, 2015
												This game is very emotionally intense. The baby badgers suck you in with their cute little barks and whimpers. And protecting them from a giant death bird bonds you for life. And then you notice that you only have four trailing behind you. So you go look for the lost baby badger, and you see him gray and lifeless a ways back. Or you'll see your pups run off only to have there be one less when they get back. And that's really hard. I'm sure there are some folks who can handle that; personally I cried like a dingo ate my baby when the last one got swept away in a flood. From an artistic standpoint, this game is flawless. It hooks the player in and gets them emotionally attached to its nameless little characters, each one with its own individual patterning. And it'll rip your heart out. Play with caution.

Posted: August 26, 2015
												*************POSSIBLE SPOILER************Shelter was a very beautiful and emotional game but it is short. The game doesn't need to be any longer than it is, the animations are a bit glitchy and sometimes there may be a graphical error but beyond that Shelter was amazing. The music in the game should also be acknowledged- it both helps translate the raw and guttural emotions of being a mother badger to the player as well as paint the scene for each stage. Though proceed with caution- the game is not so much about your survival; it is about taking care of these five little cubs. Each of them are almost constantly hungry, and even as they age and are less prone to hunger, as a mother badger- you (or at least I have felt this way) will still proceed to feed and protect them. ~~~~ VERY LIKELY TO BE A SPOILER ~~~~You feed and protect these, in your heart, still baby badgers until your final breath. The final stage was incredibly dramatic. Though they are now grown and capable of fending off for themselves, you still mother them and until that moment you are stripped away from them- they depend on you for their safety. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~So anyway, this is my first review. It's a short game, beautiful, touching, well executed and it has a very strong musical accompaniment. I'd suggest this game to anyone looking for a break from the normal gore and willing to step into a new kind of violence. A gracful  one that is likely to be very realistic with one that actually exists, just more descretely in our lives but painfully apparent through this game.

Posted: August 25, 2015
												Shelter is a game where you play as a Mother Badger and must look after your 5 children. To look after them you must lead them to safety while making sure they are fed. To ensure their safety you must run and hide in thick grass from a Hawk, lead them across raging rapids, and help them escape from a fire. You scavenge food for them, which could be anywhere from plants in the ground to fruits in trees to catching live prey and letting them feast upon its miserable existence. If you lose 1 of your children to anything you must protect them from or if you let them go hungry, it is a sad and emotional feeling that is created upon seeing it pass away. The game has a heart wrenching end that is almost guaranteed to bring you to tears. If you have about 2 hours to spare, buy this and play it, you will not regret your decision.

Posted: July 17, 2016
												It's something different from what I'm used to play. Also it's different from other survival games, since here you must take care of your children while you yourself seem to be untaouchable and can't die of starvation. The game also has a rather unique graphics solution. An excellent example of how you can make a beautiful game with low graphics. It's very beautiful in an artistic way.Gameplay is simple - explore, find food to feed your cubs and protect them from various dangers. Your primary goal is to get ahead, explore untill eventually you reach the end. Food source is limited despite the fact that you can harvest fruit, vegetables and even hunt small or not that smal animals, so it's best not to linger too long in one place, but keep moving ahead.As for the cons: There's no tutorial to start you up. You start the game in a cave unaware of what you can and must do. Luckily community guides can help (spoler: that little white furry thing that apears to be dead is not dead, it just needs food)There are some elements of a tuturial in a form of flash images that display a message, but in my oppinion, it's not enough. I saw a picture of rocks in a river, I suspected it might indicate that we can hide behind rocks, but I was not sure about that and did not wan't to risk it... Yeah I should've hid behind the rocks.Over all I like the game and I will buy the sequel, but it was really short. I finished the game in about half an hour and later replayed it to end it in the best way possible and now I don't see myslef playing it again. It's nice and I enjoyed it, but the reply value is really low.

Posted: May 28, 2016
												Shelter is a charming and quite moving game with a striking art style. It suffers from a number of minor bugs, and slightly awkward controls and camera, but nothing that significantly diminishes the overall experiences. That said, it's worth pointing out that the game has a playtime of only just over an hour and lacks the variety between playthroughs to merit many replays, so bear that in mind.I would recommend this game for anyone into more arty games, or who is looking for an emotionally powerful game with more gameplay and mechanics than you find in other genres like walking simulators. Further, this is a good example of a "short and sweet" game that won't waste your time, so if you're time poor and looking to fill an evening, this is a good choice. In addition, if you're considering whether to buy this or Shelter 2, I would say this is the superior experience and would recommend you try it (even if you think lynxes are cooler than badgers).

Totally worth my money!Big plusses in my opinion:- Wonderful Art Direction- Wonderful Audio Design- Simple easy to learn mechanics.- An UI that doesnt break immersion.Some downsides:- I seemed to bug one of the eagles- The end and the tears.

Posted: June 2, 2016
												I'm obsessed with this game, the art, the music, the concept, everything about this game was done beautifully! Won't comment on the ending of course since it's pretty much the only thing that can actually be spoiled, but I barely made it with all 5 of my babies! (whom I named of course; Mini Me, Zero, Stripe, Beatle, and Orion)The game can be intense, it becomes immersive very quick so when you lose a baby there's a real sense of panic which I hated and appreciated at the same time hahaPeople had been rather harsh on judging this game so I was a bit skeptical at first but imo, everything about it was done perfectly 15/10 would pay to stress over virtual badger babies again.

Posted: May 28, 2016
												It's midnight and a soft yelp from behind me indicates that my first pup has been claimed by the creatures of the night. I would lose two more over the course of my journey.  Disheartened, I took a step back to remind myself that this was only a game and the burden I felt from the loss of my pup was unwarrented.Rather than calling it a game, Shelter unfolds into something closer to interactive art. The soundtrack is alluring and aptly sets the scene for a surpsiginly emotional (if short) adventure. The relationships you develop with your pups will evoke feelings from you in a way that only art can do.I would not say this game is quite worth its current price of $9.99, but if you happen to catch Shelther on sale, you will not regret the purchase.

												Shelter is a game with an interesting concept but deeply flawed implementation. Posted: December 28, 2013
												A short yet beautiful adventure where your maternal/paternal instincts take over. It's a charming and short game about motherhood and trying to protect your young in a cold world. The game clocks in a little over an hour yet it doesn't overstay its welcome with its simplistic mechanics of feeding your young, trying to keep them together and keeping them from being devoured. The game is pretty simple but keeping your young alive is surprisingly difficult and over the course of your hour you'll find plenty of twists and turns and new mechanics to keep things free. You'll mostly be wandering around, trying to feed your children by either knocking down apples or even hunting small animals. There will even be times where you are met with more children than food and you have to choose who to feed (hungry children will fade and grow weaker and slower making them easy prey). Avoiding eagles, creatures of the night, trying to keep them calm when they run away scared and keeping them alive during natural disasters makes you grow attached to them. My only criticism is that for a game so short there are loading screens (which are quick) but load into very different areas of the forest. Such a short game would have been much better at providing a more seamless transition between the "areas" of the forest. All in all it's a great game.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												This game is brilliant, I began intending to play causally, not really caring too much about the cubs but by the time I got to the (spoilers) Eagle I was so afraid for the cubs, I was devastated when Luke was taken, if you want to come away from this game unscaithed, whatever you do, DON'T NAME THE CUBS! It's too late for me, but I've still got Badger, Rob, Frog and Sir Bastion, and I'll die before anything happens to them!

Posted: May 28, 2016
												Shelter is a charming and quite moving game with a striking art style. It suffers from a number of minor bugs, and slightly awkward controls and camera, but nothing that significantly diminishes the overall experiences. That said, it's worth pointing out that the game has a playtime of only just over an hour and lacks the variety between playthroughs to merit many replays, so bear that in mind.I would recommend this game for anyone into more arty games, or who is looking for an emotionally powerful game with more gameplay and mechanics than you find in other genres like walking simulators. Further, this is a good example of a "short and sweet" game that won't waste your time, so if you're time poor and looking to fill an evening, this is a good choice. In addition, if you're considering whether to buy this or Shelter 2, I would say this is the superior experience and would recommend you try it (even if you think lynxes are cooler than badgers).

Posted: December 14, 2014
												If I could describe this game in two words, it would be beautiful, and sad. The game basically revolves around you, the Badger mother, trying to keep your kin alive. You harvest food, sneak around (There are birds that hunt you, and yes, they are frieghtening), and explore. The game sets a tone of bright and innocent in earlier levels, and becomes dark and depressing in later stages. I personally fell in love with the kin and really, REALLY, wanted them all to survive. But, this objective was diminished in one level where it seemed impossible to get through without one of the small badgers dying (leaving only a peep noise). This made me very angry as it seemed like a design choice, ruining my experiance. But maybe this is the devs teaching us something....You can't always have what you want, your heart WILL be broken and sometimes there is nothing you can do about it. Maybe im thinking about it too much. I did cry (like a little ♥♥♥♥♥) when I first finished the game and was a little disappointed about the ending (see previous points). But overall this game was a great experiance and I highly recommend it to everyone!!! 8.5/10

Then!Saw SHADOW OF WINGS, hid in grass with babies,ran over open flat dirt to more grass, shadow dived at us but not fast enough, we are safe, hid under a tree trunk checking everyone under with me, ran to next good cover, WINGS, almost there, run babies, ruNNOONOOOOO, make an involuntary embarrassing squeaky cry of anguish in real life as an Eagle flies away with my slowest baby......4 babies with mommy now.OH THE FEELS!10/10 Would run from Eagle with my pups again

												Definitely an “artsy” game. If you aren’t the type of person who sees games as another form of artistic expression, don’t bother with this. The graphics are a stylized, washed-out look and the gameplay is minimalistic, to put it generously. It seems extremely insubstantial for MSRP, and if I had paid that I’d feel cheated. However, 50% or more off and I’d be happy with the purchase.Just a note: developer, why did you pick the most evil animal on Earth for us to be sympathetic for? Maybe that was the cunning plan: to show those terrifying creatures from Farcry 4 to just be trying to survive…by biting people’s legs off.

Posted: March 24, 2015
												A simple but immersive game where you play a mother badger trying to shepard five cubs through the merciless natural world, eating everything in sight to try and keep them alive. You will dread the darkness, fear the fire, and hurl invective skyward at those ****ing eagles. There's no real complex mechanics at work, and the fact that everything is pretty straightforward lends itself greatly to the immersive experience. There's no stopping to try and remember how to do something. You pretty much run forward and bite things. Or threaten to bite things. You're a badger, biting is kind of your thing.The only frustrating point I ran into was when the mother badger apparently bugged and wouldn't drop a piece of food. This created obvious eating-related problems for her cubs on that level... A cub had passed out from hunger and then been eaten in the darkness, so I guess she was hanging onto it to try and revive him, but it was too late for that. I guess the moral of that story is: don't dwell on the past, you've got hungry badgerlets to feed in the present.9/10 would learn valuable life lessons again

Posted: January 3, 2016
												I don't get what other people were seeing in this. I don't hate it, I just don't recommend it to others. Shelter is a game where you are a mother badger escorting 5 smaller badgers to a different part of the forest. But Oh No! There are foxes, hawks, fires, floods, and more along the journey. The game begins with only 4 cubs and a grey one that appears dead on the floor. Without tutorial, you're supposed to know that to proceed you need to feed the baby badger a root. This never comes up again and it feels needless. After that, you proceed to learn how to get food (which you already did), how to hide, how to bark, and why you should hide. The problem is that's about it. The entire game is basically the tutorial portion repeated a few times. You'll find yourself in several hawk chase scenes and they just don't feel tense after the first one because its just the same scenerio over and over. The hawk squaks ever time you walk out of the grass, regardless of where it's shadow is and you "just" make it every time. My other problem with this game is that for a baby escort game, there's a lot of times where you'll find yourself saying "Why did my baby die this time?" Additionally, the gamma here is horrendous. Everything looks like your screen's blacklight is malfunctioning, but there's no way to change the visual settings. On top of that, there's a number of graphical glitches, such as floating trees and the camera constantly clipping or otherwise being annoying. I didn't even feel particularly sad when my baby badgers died because at first I thought it was scripted and since I'm not controling them, I have no ability to stop them from getting ?eaten by an owl? or swooped up by a hawk. For that reason, I don't even understand the "crying into a pillow" meme that litters the positive review section.

Posted: December 15, 2015
												9/10 A little gem. Beautiful art, simple but well-designed game mechanics. The chief merit of this game is how it challenges the typical narrative frames within which most games operate to provide a truly compelling--emotionally compelling--gaming experience. Sounds silly, but as a mother badger, you get very emotionally invested in keeping your little cubs alive. I've done my fair share of "escort quests" in MMO's, but this--whether because of how utterly dependent the cubs are or how unstoppable some of the predators are--really stirs your protective instincts. Not sure whether non-parent players will experience the same thing. That moment when you look behind you and you only see four cubs where there were five a moment ago is truly disheartening. I confess I didn't do so well on my first play-through (which took less than an hour). So I tried again, armed with my knowledge of the maps and mechanics--and did a little better. The ending of this little narrative is powerful.The only thing that knocks this down to 9/10 is that it crashed on Mac (a QA misstep acknowledged by the studio), forcing me to replay almost an entire level.Hats off to Johannes Wadin and Might & Delight. I confess I was a little disappointed to see they have made a sequel. A major appeal of this game is how one-of-a-kind it is. I'm not sure what a sequel can add.

Posted: March 1, 2015
 What a great game Shelter is an emotional journey through the harsh forest as a mother badger. I absolutely loved it, and it taught me a thing or two about how hard it is for creatures in the wild to survive. Here are the positives: The artwork is beautifully simple, and adds to the atmosphere of the gameThe story keeps you interested with the different things that happen (I won't give too much away!)The music is intriguing and adds to the storyThe game makes you feel like you really are the mother badger, having to protect your cubs, and therefore pulls at some heartstrings throughout the story. And here are some negatives:The main story is relatively short, only lasting about one and a half hours if you are going slowly and appreciating all of the artwork. However, there is a second part of the game, Nurture, where you have to go back to the game every day for about 5 - 10 minutes to check on your cubs, so that keeps you coming back for more. In Nurture, alot of it is just running up and down the map to get to your cubs which is just holding down the shift key, which can get quite boring at times.But in conclusion, I would highly recommend this game and it is defintiely worth the money that you spend on it.

												10/10 would badger my friends to play this!Shelter is a rather short game, with a cute story centering around just what nature is all about. The art and playstyle are very simple; there's nothing remotely difficult to this game, but every detail ties in to really invest your emotions into this badger family and everything they have to go through. 												This game is wonderful!, you get so immersed, and its so exciting!Any one considering to buy this game, DEFINITELY SHOULD, although the game last about an 1 hour and a half- 2 hours, there is all ways nurture mode, where you can feed and protect your cubs- without an ending, as it is endless i thinkBut this is my storyAlthough the first time i died. Basically, i was very happy- i had got to the last section, with 4 of my badgers healthy and happy, their names were Oscar, Jerry, Sam and John- I lost Joe to the waves. So i was feeding and feeding and feeding them. Then i was crossing between these two ridges. But then i heard the eagle scream, and the music came on. I was paralyzed with fear, and then the eagle took John. All my happiness went instantly. I tried to run to the closest bush, when i looked behind me to see Oscar being taken. I was filled with shock and terror- everything had changed so quickly!Eventually i gained the courage to go back, i ran into a bush- and sure enough, the eagle was there.I then spent an odd 6 minutes to find where to go. Then the music stopped, the eagle went, i sighed a sigh of relief.Then the eagle was yet again there again- BUT THERE WERE NO BUSHES AROUND!!!!!!!You can see how this can get very excitingIn went into i thin bush, the eagle was coming down and down, but i and my cubs were still alive. But a swoosh of an eagle pushed me out of the bush, then- CRUNCH- i was in the eagles arms.With mama dead, the little puny cubs had to defend themselves, i wonder what will happen to them.But the good news is that i can play stage 5 again, because a wonderful thing called save!

												This game is so good. It actually is very emotional, and i remember i picked it up when it just came out, and had probably only sold a few copies. Posted: August 26, 2015
												*************POSSIBLE SPOILER************Shelter was a very beautiful and emotional game but it is short. The game doesn't need to be any longer than it is, the animations are a bit glitchy and sometimes there may be a graphical error but beyond that Shelter was amazing. The music in the game should also be acknowledged- it both helps translate the raw and guttural emotions of being a mother badger to the player as well as paint the scene for each stage. Though proceed with caution- the game is not so much about your survival; it is about taking care of these five little cubs. Each of them are almost constantly hungry, and even as they age and are less prone to hunger, as a mother badger- you (or at least I have felt this way) will still proceed to feed and protect them. ~~~~ VERY LIKELY TO BE A SPOILER ~~~~You feed and protect these, in your heart, still baby badgers until your final breath. The final stage was incredibly dramatic. Though they are now grown and capable of fending off for themselves, you still mother them and until that moment you are stripped away from them- they depend on you for their safety. ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~So anyway, this is my first review. It's a short game, beautiful, touching, well executed and it has a very strong musical accompaniment. I'd suggest this game to anyone looking for a break from the normal gore and willing to step into a new kind of violence. A gracful  one that is likely to be very realistic with one that actually exists, just more descretely in our lives but painfully apparent through this game.

Posted: January 24
												Shelter is a very interesting game, but it's definitely not for everyone. I'm a big fan of the graphics, and while it doesn't take a very long time to finish, it can be a little confusing when trying to get the hang of things. Though the story is very linear, it definitely had a strong impact on me and my experience. I guess you'll have to play it to find out.

Posted: February 7
												You play a badger mother caring for her babies. The story is as poetic as the music. The sounds emerse you in the wilds which are beautifully rendered as a patterned motif of pastels. Meander through the wonders and dangers of nature while caring for your young, finding them food and sheltering them from the varous perils that you face along the journey. Challenging, fun and relaxing. It is a story told without words and it's bittersweet. I love this game. Looking forward to playing Shelter 2 and other Might and Delight creations!

Posted: February 15
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Shelter is a game developed and published by Might and DelightThere is no questioning that Shelter is a work of art. It employs a graphics style all its own, the end result of which delivers at once a realistic and alien world. The natural environment is at once your friend and enemy, and you and your five badger cubs must make a truly hazadarous journey through itCan you provide enough food for each badger cub to survive? Can you guide them safely past the flying bird's shadow? Can you hope to navigate them all past the deadly rapids? When the forest is aflame, can you quickly discover the safest route? Everything is questioned when in natureShelter is a tense and emotional experience you should make time to play. The whole game isn't much longer than an hour or two in length, but that brief time spent is really something remarkable RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: January 12
												Right from the get go life and death are right in your face. You spend this (concise) game caring for your cubs but facing the harsh realities of the circle of life. It was very honest. It communicated a lot in a very short time. It left quite an impression and I reflected on it for a while afterwards.

Posted: December 21, 2014
												Shelter is a touching and unique experience, highly recommended to any animal lover. You will experience the beautiful and dangerous aspects of nature through the eyes of an animal. However, I bought it on sale (90% off) and I would not recommend to pay full price for it since it's a very short experience (a little more than 1 hour).
